item.title: New Mobile App Allows Volunteers to Log Community Service Hours
item.dc:creator: mikequery
item.content:encoded:
If there's one thing we should make sure to do, it's to make sure that those who love to give have whatever they need to keep on giving. One space in the new mobile digital world that has yet to see a dominant force emerge is local community service volunteering. Every city, town, or neighborhood has their share of do-gooders looking to make a tangible difference, for reasons that vary - high schoolers want to rack up the community service hours to impress prospective colleges, and others find motivation through various life experiences. Organizations that we support, such as E-Soccer, E-Karate, and XCED, rely heavily on volunteers. One thing that has been lacking in our smart phone populated world is an effective way for our volunteers to keep track of progress and get others involved, which is exactly the need that this new app addresses. Reward Volunteers is an iPhone app that allows users to keep track of their community service work and get their friends involved via Facebook. The idea is that volunteer work is something that is better when done with friends, and that keeping track of the time you've spent shouldn't be a chore. It also incentivizes more giving with prizes that are given to both volunteers, and the organizations they support. How effective is this app? Does it really motivate volunteers to keep giving? And, perhaps importantly, does it encourage inactive friends of volunteers to get involved?

How it works

Volunteers start the process by downloading the iPhone app, which will ask them to log in using Facebook connect. Once connected, they can add organizations where they participate at, and begin adding hours once they've completed their work. Each time they add hours contributed, Reward Volunteers offers to post to Facebook with a link to both the app and the organization's page. While testing it, we were able to log hours to E-Soccer after finding it immediately (as it is linked to its Facebook page). Each time a volunteer logs hours, they accrue "Reach" points, which ultimately increase chances that either the user or the organization will receive prizes. The prizes are distributed at the end of whichever phase the program is in (the current one ends on Jan. 21, 2013). While the prize incentives are exciting, the true value seems to come from the ability to have a streamlined method of both logging hours and inspiring friends via social media. It will be interesting to see how organizations like E-Soccer can benefits from seeing volunteers they rely on spread the word effortlessly.

By the numbers

Reward Volunteers just finished a successful first phase which followed its launch in February of this year. Between Feb. 14 and July 7, volunteers from 46 states logged more than 44,000 hours at over 800 organizations that ranged from Earth protection groups to social services orgs (E-Soccer would fall under this category). It's unclear, however, how many of these users were inactive prior to being inspired by friends on Facebook. This metric would be a very helpful data point for Chalo Inc. if they can figure out how to acquire it. The second phase on August 27, 2012 with all new prizes including cash for organizations, cash for individuals, VT farm vacations and much more. Hours logged between July 8, 2012 and January 21, 2013 count in Reward Volunteers 2.0. $30,000 was distributed to organizations and individuals during the first phase, and others won various cash and vacation incentives.
item.excerpt:encoded: Reward Volunteers lets users share their volunteer experiences and receive awards

item.title: Believing in Answered Prayers
item.dc:creator: decemberqts
item.content:encoded: ● Faith - God Believing in Answered Prayers Scripture Daniel 9:20-23 NLT I went on praying and confessing my sin and the sin of my people, pleading with the Lord my God for Jerusalem, his holy mountain. As I was praying, Gabriel, whom I had seen in the earlier vision, came swiftly to me at the time of the evening sacrifice. He explained to me, “Daniel, I have come here to give you insight and understanding. The moment you began praying, a command was given. And now I am here to tell you what it was, for you are very precious to God. Listen carefully so that you can understand the meaning of your vision. Questions What have you been praying for that you are waiting for an answer? Sometimes when we pray we don't believe God hears us or wants to answer. And sometimes we don't pray specifically so we're not disappointed. Do you get emotional when you pray? Describe. When we engage our emotions in prayer like Daniel did we can connect with God and move God to act. Additional Thoughts It's a great time of year to spice up your prayer life. Here are some suggestions: - Read the whole chapter of Daniel 9 - Pray through a psalm a day (pray about what the psalm says) - Pray with a friend either over the phone or on a walk - Recount or write down prayers you have seen God answer.

item.title: Tough Love - Part I
item.dc:creator: mikequery
item.content:encoded:
This is a picture of Dynesha Lax, a mom of a fourteen-year-old teenage boy who just can't seem to keep himself out of trouble. When Dynesha wasn’t satisfied with the punishment of conventional law, she took matters into her own hands and made her son wear a poster that read: I lie. I steal. I sell drugs. I don’t follow the law. When bystanders saw this, some called the police and reported the incident. However, she was within her rights as a parent, so the police couldn’t do anything. When interviewed, she said, “They've got their way of parenting and I've got mine. My object is to save my son.” Obviously, this is a controversial situation. Some say she is out of her mind and is being abusive to her son. Others say she is a great mom helping her son turn from his destructive choices. Regardless of your perspective on this situation, parents can be sure of one thing: teens need tough love if they are going to develop into the person they are meant to be. And what is tough love? Tough love is when a parent puts their teenager through discipline because they have a clear vision of who their teen is supposed to be in the future.
  • Tough love means not being swayed when your teenager tries to manipulate you and make you feel bad for disciplining them.
  • Tough love means your goal is not for your teen to like you, but for your teen to become who they are meant to be.
  • Tough love is when a parent acts for their teen’s best interests, and is not afraid to say “no.”
Our fathers on earth disciplined us for a short time in the way they thought was best. But God disciplines us to help us, so we can become holy as he is. 11 We do not enjoy being disciplined. It is painful at the time, but later, after we have learned from it, we have peace, because we start living in the right way. Hebrews 12:10-11 (NCV)
In this passage, it is evident that no one enjoys being disciplined because discipline is painful; however, the pain leads to right living in the future. Teenagers typically have a hard time seeing beyond the moment, and they manipulate their parents to get out of discipline because they instinctively avoid the pain. And sadly, without tough love, parents often succumb to their teenagers’ manipulation and end up watching them go down a road that no parent wishes for their kids. The book of Proverbs has a number of passages that talk about how discipline eventually leads to our kids doing the right thing. If you are a having a hard time loving your teenager by disciplining them, imitate the heart and principles used in the following passages: Proverbs 13:24 He who spares the rod hates his son, but he who loves him is careful to discipline him. Proverbs 22:15 Folly is bound up in the heart of a child, but the rod of discipline will drive it far from him. Proverbs 23:13 Do not withhold discipline from a child; if you punish him with the rod, he will not die. Proverbs 23:14 Punish him with the rod and save his soul from death. Proverbs 29:15 The rod of correction imparts wisdom, but a child left to himself disgraces his mother.
item.excerpt:encoded: Tough love is when a parent puts their teenager through discipline because they have a clear vision of who their teen is supposed to be in the future.

item.title: 5 Tips to Have a Successful Garage Sale
item.dc:creator: mikequery
item.content:encoded:
Garage sales have historically been one of the most successful fundraising events for our annual Special Contribution. Their popularity stems not only for the convenience provided by being able to remove superfluous items from your house, but also from the experiences they provide. Being able to eat donuts with your good friends while neighbors come by to hand you money and get to know you are memories that become irreplaceable. But, how does one organize a garage sale that is not only memorable, but productive and, dare I say, lucrative? The following 5 tips will help you get started in the right direction. Ignore at your own peril!

1. Promote your event (aggressively)

The worst thing that can happen to an amazing garage sale is having no one show up! There are a number of ways to ensure that on the day of the event there are plenty of people present. Social media provides us with an excellent avenue for promoting just about anything. You can use Facebook to create an event, which you can in turn invite people to. Make sure to post about the event on your friends' timelines. If you're an avid Twitter user, make sure to tweet regularly (not too much) every day prior to the event, each time with new information about what to look forward to. You can visit our Facebook page for example of event related posts. And don't forget signs! Garage sales are local events, so make sure to create great, attractive signs to post around the neighborhood in high traffic locations. Post fliers at local grocery stores or coffee shops. Get help from someone creative if that is not your strong suit. Kids and teenagers are usually great for this.

2. Timing is everything

The date and start time of your garage sale means a lot. Try selecting a day that corresponds with typical paydays (i.e. the 1st or 15th of the month) to minimize reluctance to spend money. Make sure not to plan over a holiday weekend, as many will be out of town. And don't forget to start early...many shoppers are early birds, and want to drop in as soon as they can to get the best items before they're gone.

3. Make it attractive

There's a lot you can do to make your garage sale attractive to potential buyers, and yet to be converted onlookers. Cut your grass, clear your garage of trash and non-sale items, and do an overall cleanup. Have universally accepted, non-polarizing music such as jazz or pop music playing in the background. Clean the dust and grime off the items you're selling to make them look newer. Lastly, if you can swing it, have refreshments available. Unless you have such huge traffic that loitering becomes a problem for people looking to actually buy vs just stand around, giving people a reason to stay and make your garage sale look successful could attract people driving by.

4. Price objectively

The biggest mistake people make when pricing items for a garage sale is not removing nostalgia and sentimentality from the equation and selling items based on a realistic value. Your old teddy bear may have got you through some tough times, but it's unlikely anyone will bay $25 for it.

5. Involve the kids

Kids can play a huge role in making your garage sale effective, and there are plenty of other benefits from having them around. For one, allowing kids to set up a lemonade stand (or something similar) will attract potential buyers, and will also teach them lessons about working hard, as well as the purpose behind special contribution. It's also a great way to build family. Garage sales and other events are fantastic opportunities for families to come together and ultimately have a great time regardless of how much is sold. Whether you sell a lot or not, it's a win-win scenario!
item.excerpt:encoded: How to make sure your garage sale is not only memorable, but productive.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: 5 Tips to Have a Successful Garage Sale
Help your special contribution efforts with a solid, fun money making event

item.title: Stories From Women's Day 2012: Stronger
item.dc:creator: mikequery
item.content:encoded:
This year's Women's Day events were unlike any we've ever seen. In addition to seeing more new faces than ever before, each event brought something unique to the intricately decorated proverbial table - a story that illustrates how God works, and how he used this year's Women's Day to bring women together who otherwise would never have known each other. There were 7 total Women's Day events - one for each of the five counties that span the BACC, and two Y Women's Day events (East & West Bay). Here are some stories that describe just what took place in the month of April, and how God moves in people's lives in ways we don't expect.  

West Bay Y Women's Day - Schoolmates Coincidentally Meet

Joli Dumlao, a junior at Del Mar High School, was a speaker at this past weekend's Y Women's Day in Palo Alto. After sharing vulnerably from her life, she sat down at her table full of other teen girls who were anxious to discuss what they had heard. Unbeknownst to Joli, one of the girls at her table was a student at none of that Del Mar. She recognized her while she was speaking, and was quick to introduce herself at the table, as they had never actually met.

item.title: 2012 Women's Day Filled With Stories of God Moving
item.dc:creator: ccedillo
item.content:encoded:
26 From one man he made all the nations, that they should inhabit the whole earth; and he marked out their appointed times in history and the boundaries of their lands. 27 God did this so that they would seek him and perhaps reach out for him and find him, though he is not far from any one of us Acts 17:26-27 Probably the most exciting part of our annual Women's Day events is being able to watch how God orchestrates and moves things around for people to build new relationships; women who, if not for these events, would have otherwise had no reason to meet, let alone talk and engage about real life issues. Each year we see the results of God doing things behind the scenes to make Women's Day filled with inspiring stories, and this year was no exception. What does it mean to be a strong woman in today’s world? The 2012 Women’s Day event answered this question for several women, inspiring them to become stronger in every area of life. The event, which was held in five counties throughout the Bay Area, attracted women of all different ages and backgrounds. Women were moved by powerful lessons that were shared by married women, single women, college students, and teenagers.

Hope found in Contra Costa

At Contra Costa’s Women’s Day, a woman with a special needs child attended the event without the presupposition that there would be any content related to her situation. One of the speakers, however, spoke in depth about her life and experiences with her own special needs child. The visiting woman broke down in tears...she had not planned on being reached at this level, and was filled with relief by the notion that there was someone who could relate to her. After the event, the woman had a lengthy conversation with the speaker, as well as with two other women from the BACC who have special needs children of their own. These women went on to aide her in getting additional services for her daughter at school, as well as recommending great babysitting options. God used connections from women's day to change the life of both this woman and her daughter!

Connections made at Y Women's Day

At the West Bay's Y Women's Day, a chance encounter led to a newly formed friendship. A woman and her teen daughter attended the event, knowing only a hand full of people. One of the teens from the BACC Y Ministry, Erin, is a student at Carlmont High School in San Carlos. As it turns out, the daughter also goes to Carlmont, and almost immediately recognized Erin when she saw her. Although they were not yet friends, the connection was impossible to ignore, and led to a great conversation after. Erin's example inspired the daughter to want to attend our upcoming Teen Camp.

item.title: Campus Retreat "Breakthrough:" What it Means and Why We're Doing It
item.dc:creator: nstraw
item.content:encoded:
There are half a million reasons to be interested in what happens at our annual campus retreat entitled "Breakthrough," which takes place on October 12th in Santa Clara. The Bay Area is home to some of the most prestigious and ambitious universities in the world, and the number of young people moving here to pursue their ambitions is testimony to that. Over 575,000 students attend Bay Area colleges and universities:
  • 75,000 attend private colleges and universities such as Stanford, Santa Clara, USF and the Academy of Art
  • 150,000 attend public colleges and universities such as UC Berkeley and Santa Cruz, San Jose State, San Francisco State and CSU East Bay
  • 350,000 attend community and junior colleges such as CSM, De Anza, Foothill and DVC
With over half a million dreamers and visionaries making the Bay their home, we feel it's important to match that ambition with teaching and inspiration that goes beyond what's heard in the classroom. Our campus retreats offer teachings on life, relationships, and God in ways that relate not only to the everyday life of a college student, but to longer term visions for how we plan on making a dent in the world. We believe that within everyone lies the passion to do more than just study and get a job, and our retreats offer a glimpse of what exactly that can be through personal sharing, lessons, and social activities that promote new and strengthened relationships. This year's theme is "Breakthrough," which speaks to the personal battle we all face to overcome apathy, adversity and other hindrances that limit us in our pursuits. To breakthrough is to become who God envisions us being, despite whatever we think is holding us back. If you or a friend/family member are interested, register today and find out for yourself what's in store!

item.title: 5 Mistakes College Students Make in Building Relationships
item.dc:creator: mikequery
item.content:encoded:
We are less than a week away from our campus retreat entitled "Breakthrough," which means it's time to focus in on what exactly most college students are thinking of and experiencing on a regular basis. The retreat will cover a wide range of topics, the most important of which being relationships. Relationships have proven to be the greatest asset for success in every area of life:
I long to see you so that I may impart to you some spiritual gift to make you strong Romans 1:11
Whether you're good at building relationships or not, there's always something good to learn when it comes to getting closer to people. Check out these 5 mistakes students typically make when it comes to building relationships in college.

1. Not exploring

College is an amazing place. You'll never again find an opportunity to be around so many passionate and ambitious people with so few responsibilities holding you back. Depending on the college or university you go to, there are endless amounts of things to check out that will lead you to new and like-minded people. Check out a new club, take a class that isn't in your major course list, join an intramural team, or take part in a project to better your campus' or city's community. SpeakOut at SJSU is an example of a club doing big things, and is a great opportunity to meet new people if you're in San Jose.

2. Studying alone

Some of my closest friendships were forged while struggling together in classes we were not at all prepared or qualified for. I built a lot of memories with friends while studying - we got closer because we were in the battle together. Go check out the reading center, tutoring center, and any study session you can find to meet people and get some help in the process. The last thing you want is to go through all 4 years (or however long it takes) and not recognize the faces you see on the graduation stage.

3. Not asking for help

Plans fail for lack of counsel, but with many advisers they succeed. Proverbs 15:22
Sometimes, just asking someone for help is all you need to do to get better at something, including building relationships. Are you timid? Talk to someone who's bold. Are you insecure? Talk to someone who's confident. Just don't make the mistake of going about your day without at least talking to someone. Hopefully you have someone in your circle of friends who is different enough than you to offer you an objective perspective on how you can grow. If you don't, the retreat is a great opportunity to meet or be introduced to new people who can do just that.

4. Assuming others know how to build relationships

A big mistake college students can make is assuming that they're the only one having a tough time building relationships with other students. Or, they assume that since they're fine, others must be too. Whatever your situation is, there are for sure people around you who could either benefit from what you have, or can relate to what you're going through. Take a walk through the dorms and watch people closely. Odds are you'll see a lonely person, a suspicious person, an arrogant person...all in one trip!

5. Not taking advantage of opportunities

You'll never have another period of time in life quite like your college years. Situations come up all the time that are great opportunities to meet someone new, or build a new memory with an existing friend. I have endless stories that led to meeting people that I still keep in touch with today, years after graduation, many of which took place my first year in the dorms. I'm constantly recalling stories and adventures that never would have happened had I stayed indoors with the same couple of friends. Take advantage of every opportunity you can to meet people and build great relationships. As Ferris once told us, "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while...you might miss it."
item.excerpt:encoded: How to make sure you don't miss out on opportunities to grow.

item.title: Campus Retreat Recap - A Breakthrough Weekend
item.dc:creator: dmotamed
item.content:encoded:
This weekend saw hundreds of college students from universities around the entire Bay Area converge in Santa Clara for a weekend filled with stories of personal change and vision. Taking place at the Santa Clara Hyatt, BACC's campus retreat entitled "Breakthrough" was packed to the brim with  classes, breakout sessions and social activities that brought students together from all different backgrounds and personalities. The theme "Breakthrough" was appropriate, as most college students around this time are searching for their identity, having just begun a new school year filled with challenges, distractions, and other things that can get in the way of a finding true purpose - a reason to exist at school aside from the prospect of money and a career.
With your help I can advance against a troop ; with my God I can scale a wall. Psalm 18:29
The topic of the keynote lesson was comebacks, and it addressed overcoming setbacks in school, relationships, and life. Different breakthrough and comeback stories were featured in a video that featured an Olympic swimmer from Cal, a football all-star from San Jose State, and several others. Other speakers also shared detailed stories from their lives, touching on topics such as deep, unresolved bitterness towards family, overcoming drug abuse, and more. After a catered breakfast at the Hyatt, Saturday's classes finished the retreat strong, leading many people to make decisions to tackle feelings and life challenges with friends. This is significant considering many of those people had not had any kind of conversation that dealt with real life issues in a vulnerable way prior to the event. The responses from those experiencing this kind of event for the first time are really what make this retreat moving. One girl spent years working up the courage to talk to only one person about her battle with an eating disorder. After the sharing and classes, she spoke to an entire group about her challenges, filled with a new found hope of overcoming them. The weekend was filled with similar stories of vulnerability, but it isn't to say that it wasn't without its share of fun and goofs. Memories were built outside of the conversations and classes, and they were filled with laughs. A karaoke jam on the first night saw students unite in vulnerability, hilariously singing along to cheesy pop tunes. And, students managed to find plenty of ways to engage with the Hyatt's decor:
Campus retreat. A royal affair instagr.am/p/QvVUdJELvA/ — Chiara Marquez (@chiara_marquez) October 13, 2012
  Overall it was a memorable weekend which should give students plenty to think about and hone in on as they continue their studies into the fall, now properly equipped with inspiration and decisions made that will allow them to make the personal breakthroughs they've been searching for.

item.title: Schedule Available for Marriage Refreshment Weekend - "Faithfully"
item.dc:creator: bacc
item.content:encoded:
With less than a week to go before our annual Marriage Refreshment Weekend is underway, we're giving you a taste of what's in store by making available the schedule for the entire weekend. We packed these two days with enough opportunities to learn, converse, and relax that you will indeed be refreshed when you head home Saturday night.
I have chosen the way of faithfulness; I have set my heart on your laws. Psalm 119:30
The weekend can be summed up in the following three focuses:
  • Breaking Away - Refocusing our lives on God is the first step towards building a faithful marriage. Learn how to break away from humanism and bring God back into the picture.
  • Breaking Free - Redefining our relationships is essential for faithfulness. Learn to draw close to those who help us build our marriage.
  • Breakthrough - Becoming faithful to the dream that brought you and your spouse together
Click here to download the schedule and get yourself ready for a weekend of change for you and your spouse. Don't forget to register online, and we'll see you in Santa Clara!

item.title: The Next Chapter: God is Not Finished Yet
item.dc:creator: bacc
item.content:encoded:
This article is the first in a series of recaps from our recent Marriage Refreshment Weekend, which we're calling "Faithfully: Class Notes." We will continue to release these over the following week in order to give everyone a chance to revisit what they learned, and to give those who could not attend an opportunity to see what they missed.

Purpose/introduction

God is not finished with us yet. The great challenge for us as we age is to never stop growing and developing into new people. How are you doing in making this transition? Are you full of faith as you look at the future or fear? God promises to make us new each day no matter what stage of life we are at. This is the hope and promise that guides us through midlife and beyond. It is time to turn the page.

Scriptures

The righteous will flourish like a palm tree, they will grow like a cedar of Lebanon; planted in the house of the LORD, they will flourish in the courts of our God. They will still bear fruit in old age, they will stay fresh and green. Psalms 92:12-14 (NIV)
So we’re not giving up. How could we! Even though on the outside it often looks like things are falling apart on us, on the inside, where God is making new life, not a day goes by without his unfolding grace. These hard times are small potatoes compared to the coming good times, the lavish celebration prepared for us. There’s far more here than meets the eye. The things we see now are here today, gone tomorrow. But the things we cannot see now will last forever. 2 Corinthians 4:16-18 (M)

Idea 1: Young At Heart - Caleb

Joshua 14:10-11
  • God does not define us by our age but God looks at the heart!
  • Caleb is inspiring example of someone who did not let their age define them, but was still vigorous and faithful in his 80’s!
  • Study the lives of others in the Bible who God called in their older years: Moses at 80, Abraham & Sarah, Zechariah & Elizabeth, Noah, Enoch and others!
  • Change your mindset from “my time has passed” to “my time has come.” Admit truths about your heart. Doing good never ages!
  • Many people have reinvented in their older years: Harlan David Sanders, Ray Kroc, Julia Child, Laura Ingalls Wilder, Ronald Reagan, Ben Franklin.

Idea 2: Awaken Your Heart

Ephesians 5:14-16
  • Wake up and see the opportunities. Start with your marriage.!
Be Interested – Proverbs 3:27
  • Are you still interested in each other? Goals, worries, fears, temptations, and discouragements?
  • Are you taking note of each other’s changes?
Be Honest – Ephesians 4:25
  • Stop avoiding the truth, start talking about heart truths.
  • What topics do you not want to talk about with your spouse?
Be Outward – Philippians 2:3-4
  • All research on marital happiness shows that couples bond more closely when they do new, innovative activities – instead of getting stuck in the same rut of doing the same old things you’ve done for the past 30 years.
  • What can you do together as a couple that you were never able to do with kids at home? Help each other create a healthier lifestyle.
Be Caring & Affectionate – 1 Corinthians 13:4-7 (AMP)
  • In good relationships partners accept that vulnerability comes with years. They take care of one another as they deal with physical challenges and aging. They learn to be more emotionally honest.

Questions/Application

  1. What discussions and truths do you and your spouse need to talk about that you have been avoiding? Do you know where each other are at spiritually and emotionally? Temptations, guilt, fears, worries,
  2. How spiritual your peer relationships? When is last time you built a new relationship with someone much younger than you? Are you willing to be open with them and invite them into your life?
  3. What can you and your spouse do together that is outward focused and serves the community? Put together a list of friends and people you know who’s lives you could change by working together.

Additional Reading

  • Books of the Bible: Genesis, Exodus, Psalms, 1 & 2 Timothy

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The great challenge for us as we age is to never stop growing and developing into new people.

God is not finished with us yet. The great challenge for us as we age is to never stop growing and developing into new people. How are you doing in making this transition? Are you full of faith as you look at the future or fear? God promises to make us new each day no matter what stage of life we are at. This is the hope and promise that guides us through midlife and beyond. It is time to turn the page.

item.title: New Service Connects Bay Area Residents to Caregiver and CNA Jobs
item.dc:creator: mikequery
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea Cramer is part of the myCNAjobs recruitment squad, dedicated to connecting caregivers to meaningful job opportunities. myCNAjobs is a place for caregivers to get trained and find work and for senior employers to hire caregivers more effectively. Professional Caregiving Jobs are on the rise in the state of California as hundreds of Baby Boomers retire each day in the State. It's estimated in the next 20 years that the number of California residents over age 85 will reach 2 million. Healthcare jobs, including California caregiver jobs, are expected to increase rapidly in the years to come. With a looming caregiver workforce shortage, myCNAjobs - a newer service to the Bay Area - now connects Caregivers and Certified Nursing Assistants directly to caregiver job opportunities at senior home care agencies, nursing homes, and assisted living communities. There's great demand for caring, kind, dependable, and compassionate people to serve a variety of caregiver roles from non-certified to certified positions. Non-certified caregivers don't require any formal education (although it's encouraged) and certified nursing assistants require a short program at a local CNA school to learn the ropes of daily caregiver duties. Caregiver duties typically include:
  • Being a good companion and conversationalist (sharing and learning from the elderly population can often be very inspirational for the caregiver as well)
  • Meal planning and preparation
  • Assistance getting around and to/from appointments
  • Light housekeeping
  • Grooming assistance
Being a caregiver can make a big difference in someone’s life while also providing income to grow in your own life and community. Further, caregiving tends to offer flexible schedules and working with an agency offers ongoing training and learnings along the way. To learn more or to apply for Bay Area Caregiver Jobs, visit myCNAjobs.com. Additional Resources:
  • Caregiver Job Application
  • Caregiver Interviewing Tips
  • Caregiver & CNA Pay Guide

item.title: When God Isn't Attractive
item.dc:creator: austenmc
item.content:encoded: When God Isn't Attractive - An Innovative Guide for Developing an Inspirational Relationship with God. Russell Ewell, Internationally known for his passionate speaking style and extensive knowledge of the Bible, brings life to the scriptures and demonstrates how current and applicable God's word is to every person in every stage of life.  As an evangelist, husband and father of three, he infuses his personal lessons and more than 25 years of experience in spiritual counseling to convince even the most skeptical to view God through fresh eyes and a different, life-changing perspective.  In 2007 he received a Jefferson Award as well as a Congressional Citation from Congressman Tom Lantos in recognition of his impact on youth and special needs children in the San Francisco Bay Area. His first publication under the BACC Press When God Isn't Attractive has shipped to over twenty states and ten countries. Christianity is at a crossroads. In the face of increasing numbers of people choosing "none of the above" when selecting from the various denominational offerings, it is apparent that organized religion is failing to meet the spiritual needs of the average person. Despite new plans, programs and the increasing popularity of the Mega Church, thousands of churches continue to close their doors every year. In When God Isn't Attractive, Russell Ewell offers a unique blend of insights from over twenty-five years of innovative ministry experience, the scriptures and an understanding of numerous disciplines outside religion. He introduces us to a new way of thinking about Christianity where God is at the center rather than people, religion, or emotion. Religious rules, assumptions and traditions are tossed aside as he points to a future with a new kind of believer that will make God attractive and change the world. An inquiringly original assessment of religion in the 21st century, this book provides hope to those who have been turned off by organized religion and the God it presents. Ewell's deep thinking, disruptive ideas and willingness to admit that he still has a great deal to learn make this a refreshing and hopeful read. We are ready to ship. To order go to www.baccpress.com and order now. We will ship next day.

Russell Ewell, Internationally known for his passionate speaking style and extensive knowledge of the Bible, brings life to the scriptures and demonstrates how current and applicable God's word is to every person in every stage of life. As an evangelist, husband and father of three, he infuses his personal lessons and more than 25 years of experience in spiritual counseling to convince even the most skeptical to view God through fresh eyes and a different, life-changing perspective. In 2007 he received a Jefferson Award as well as a Congressional Citation from Congressman Tom Lantos in recognition of his impact on youth and special needs children in the San Francisco Bay Area.

item.title: Believing Prayer
item.dc:creator: scott
item.content:encoded:
The big challenge in our spiritual lives is not just to pray, but to believe when we pray.  The Scriptures tell us that belief is the most important part of effective prayer:
If you believe, you will receive whatever you ask for in prayer.

Matthew 21:22

Therefore I tell you, whatever you ask for in prayer, believe that you have received it, and it will be yours.

Mark 11:24

Often we get frustrated and quit praying because we lose our faith.   Below, we will focus on prayer.  But not just prayer, believing prayer. What does it take to have believing prayers? 1- A Clear mind and Self-Control
 The end of all things is near.  Therefore be clear minded and self-controlled so that you can pray.

1 Peter 4:7

a.     Are you preparing yourself to have believing prayers by calming down, clearing your mind and handling your reactions? i.     How does anger inhibit your prayers? ii.     How does anxiety inhibit your prayers? iii.     How can you handle your anger and anxiety more spiritually? 2- A Good Marriage
 Husbands, in the same way be considerate as you live with your wives, and treat them with respect as the weaker partner and as heirs with you of the gracious gift of life, so that nothing will hinder your prayers.

1 Peter 3:7

a.     Husbands, are you engaging your wife on a spiritual level in conversation? b.     Do you and your spouse spend time in the Bible? c.     Are you “considering” how to build your wife’s faith? 3- Spiritual Energy and Investment
 Never be lacking in zeal, but keep your spiritual fervor, serving the Lord.  Be joyful in hope, patient in affliction, faithful in prayer.  Share with the Lord’s people who are in need. Practice hospitality.

Romans 12:11-13

a. How can you invest more energy and zeal into your spiritual life? 4- Awareness of need
Is anyone among you in trouble? Let them pray. Is anyone happy? Let them sing songs of praise.

James 5:13

He will answer the prayers of the needy; he will not reject their prayers.

Psalm 102:17 (NCV)

a. What are the needs in your life, your family, and your friend’s lives that require prayer? 5- Openness
Therefore confess your sins to each other and pray for each other so that you may be healed. The prayer of a righteous person is powerful and effective.

James 5:16

a.     What sins do you need to confess to clear the way to have believing prayers? b.     Is there anything going on in your life that you are not open about? What happens when you pray believing prayers? 1-     Grow in Strength

As soon as I pray, you answer me; you encourage me by giving me strength.

Psalm 138:3 (NLT) 

2- Change People’s Lives
Accept instruction from his mouth and lay up his words in your heart. If you return to the Almighty, you will be restored:  If you remove wickedness far from your tent and assign your nuggets to the dust, your gold of Ophir to the rocks in the ravines, then the Almighty will be your gold, the choicest silver for you. Surely then you will find delight in the Almighty and will lift up your face to God. You will pray to him, and he will hear you, and you will fulfill your vows. What you decide on will be done, and light will shine on your ways. When people are brought low and you say, ‘Lift them up!’  then he will save the downcast. He will deliver even one who is not innocent, who will be delivered through the cleanness of your hands.

Job 22:22-30

item.title: The Real Thing: Why Conviction Matters
item.dc:creator: scott
item.content:encoded:
The world needs people who have convictions. We look up to people with conviction, people with immovable beliefs who change societies, who are willing to suffer, to wait and to persevere.  We don’t have to agree with them or what they are doing to respect and admire the personal conviction they have that produces change. Sometimes their passion makes us feel small, make us feel ashamed that we live such small lives, and makes us realize that we lack that kind of personal conviction ourselves.
Personal conviction is something everyone can have and needs to have and needs to develop.   God wants personal conviction, not robotic follower-ship.   He wants us convinced deep in our bones.  He wants this oozing out of my pours and out of my skin.  He wants us fully persuaded, not just obedient.
We always thank God for all of you and continually mention you in our prayers. We remember before our God and Father your work produced by faith, your labor prompted by love, and your endurance inspired by hope in our Lord Jesus Christ.  For we know, brothers and sisters loved by God, that he has chosen you, because our gospel came to you not simply with words but also with power, with the Holy Spirit and deep conviction. You know how we lived among you for your sake.                                                                    1 Thessalonians 1:2-5
It matters how the Gospel message of God comes into your life:
  • Not just with words – listening to a sermon or Bible study
  • Power – changing your life
  • Holy Spirit – no human explanation for what is happening
  • Deep conviction – Deeply held beliefs.
Deep conviction does not fluctuate based on emotions, circumstances, opinions, who is around, what is happening in life.  It is a motivation that cannot be taken away. Conviction is shown in how we live.  Often we don’t understand our lives - Why do we burn through marriages, boyfriends, decisions, or jobs?  This can happen because we have convictions that are wrong, or we don’t have any.  We are like jellyfish without them – carried along by life.  We don’t stand for anything and don’t believe in anything.

The Conviction-less Person is... Indecisive

But when you ask, you must believe and not doubt, because the one who doubts is like a wave of the sea, blown and tossed by the wind. That person should not expect to receive anything from the Lord. Such a person is double-minded and unstable in all they do.
James 1:6-8
  • have a hard time making decisions
  • constantly second-guess themselves
  • are unstable in dating, jobs, relationships because they lack anchors that guide their decisions.

Immature

Then we will no longer be infants, tossed back and forth by the waves, and blown here and there by every wind of teaching and by the cunning and craftiness of people in their deceitful scheming. Instead, speaking the truth in love, we will grow to become in every respect the mature body of him who is the head, that is, Christ.                                                                               Ephesians 4:14-15
  • are easily tossed back and forth
  • Constantly move on for new starts
  • Have no roots, no real relationships
  • are hard to build family with because they are always changing

Vulnerable

These people are springs without water and mists driven by a storm. Blackest darkness is reserved for them. For they mouth empty, boastful words and, by appealing to the lustful desires of the flesh, they entice people who are just escaping from those who live in error. They promise them freedom, while they themselves are slaves of depravity—for “people are slaves to whatever has mastered them.”
                                                                               2 Peter 2:17-19
  • get seduced and enticed easily because they do not believe in anything and do not stand for anything.

Hypocritical

Woe to you, teachers of the law and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You clean the outside of the cup and dish, but inside they are full of greed and self-indulgence Matthew 23:25
  • Focused on the outside looking good and never develop the inside.
  • Get weak inside because all efforts are put into appearance.
  • Are dead inside, lack passion because everything they do is to look good.
  • So How Do I Build A Conviction? Look at Paul --  He got conviction that changed the course of his life. 1. We must be convicted to get a conviction Read Acts 9:1-9 -What does it feel like to get convicted?  It is our conscience awakening. It is to have feelings like, I can’t believe that is me.  I can’t believe I am like this. It is to be stopped, arrested, to start asking questions like Paul: Who are you Lord, Who am I? What have I done? Who am I affecting?  I have killed all of these people? What does God really think about that?  Could I be wrong? What should I do? -When was the last time you got convicted? 2. We must be convinced to get a conviction Read Acts 9:17-22. -We have to be persuaded and convinced.  We have to be taught.  We have to be see and embrace the truth.  We have to ask is this worth it for me?  Why is it worth it?  This is why we need to read and study the Bible. -When we believe in something really strongly we want to convince others.  We don't worry about looking foolish. Am I ...
  • Convinced every person needs to live by the Bible?
  • Convinced I need to pray and need God’s help?
  • Convinced that this is best way to live, best life?
  • Convinced that life without God is empty?
  • Convinced that God will be with me in hard times?
Decisions: Are you a person of conviction?  Do you want to become one?
  • Get in relationships where you get convicted
  • Read your Bible and get convinced yourself.

item.title: What Matters Most
item.dc:creator: scott
item.content:encoded:
By the grace God has given me, I laid a foundation as a wise builder, and someone else is building on it. But each one should build with care.  For no one can lay any foundation other than the one already laid, which is Jesus Christ. If anyone builds on this foundation using gold, silver, costly stones, wood, hay or straw,  their work will be shown for what it is, because the Day will bring it to light. It will be revealed with fire, and the fire will test the quality of each person’s work. If what has been built survives, the builder will receive a reward. If it is burned up, the builder will suffer loss but yet will be saved—even though only as one escaping through the flames.                                                                        1 Corinthians 3:10-15
When I was young, my friends and I wanted to build a soap box derby race car. We made designs, we gathered the material we would need and we went to work. As we worked we learned that it was much harder and was taking much more time than we expected. We grew impatient and decided to use duct tape to hold it all together. We then spent considerable time on the outside; painting, making racing stripes, and making it look really cool. We took our masterpiece to the top of a big hill and prepared for glory. It traveled about 20 feet before completely falling apart, because it was not well built. Turns out duct tape does not hold things together as well as we thought. That experience reminds me of this scripture and is an illustration of what can happen when I become fatigued and impatient building my family. Families cannot be held together by duct tape; instead they must be built well. Convictions are the materials with which great families are built. Building families with conviction is the greatest endeavor any of us can undertake. The first thing we need to know about convictions is that they are not cheap. If you want a deep conviction you will have to pay for it. In fact, we have to pay a high price for convictions. But a family built on convictions is worth every penny, because, when it comes to building a family, convictions are what matter most. How are you building your family? What areas of family building am I currently holding together with duct tape? (Marriage, Finances, Intimacy) What convictions can I purchase through Bible study, openness, and prayer? Here are some scriptures to get us started building. Luke 6:46-49 Proverbs 14:11 Proverbs 15:6 Proverbs 24:2-4
item.excerpt:encoded: The first thing we need to know about convictions is that they are not cheap.

item.title: Bringin' the Heat!
item.dc:creator: gbodzioch
item.content:encoded: Las Vegas, Nevada is one of the hottest places in the Western Hemisphere throughout the year. Already well known for its uniquely high heat index which averages a whopping 103 degrees yearly during the summer, Las Vegas is now also “bringin’ the heat” of inspiration for many special needs families throughout the community who have thirsted long for more opportunities for their children. Through developing friendships and relationship connections between the Greater Las Vegas Church of Christ and the Bay Area Christian Church, the Las Vegas Church has launched an exciting extension of our Bay Area E-Soccer Program. “Hear the Cry”: E-Soccer/Hope for God’s Children (www.esoccerlv.com) launched in March of 2011 and is already reaching and serving 60+ special needs and typical kids in the community! We are inspired by the enthusiasm of the brothers and sisters in Las Vegas who have embraced the passion to provide opportunity and serve families with special needs in their area. It reignites our gratitude here in the Bay Area for this incredible program. We are thankful for the connections we are building with the Las Vegas Church and we see how God uses these friendships to meet needs and spur us higher – to “bring the heat” in making a felt difference for families! Here at home, we are "turning up the heat" on Saturday, April 23rd at our Spring 2011 E-Soccer Coaches Training from 10 am – 12:30 pm at Canada College in Redwood City. This training session will be comprehensive in how to work with different types of special needs, soccer drills and games, and more. Anyone who attendees will receive phenomenal professional training from US Soccer Coaching staff (www.ussoccercoaching.com) as well as from physical/occupational therapists and long-time E-Soccer veterans regarding how to work with different special needs in the sports/soccer environment. We are also very excited to host a group of the new Las Vegas E-Soccer coaches who will be attending for the weekend!
item.excerpt:encoded: The Las Vegas Church has launched an exciting extension of our Bay Area E-Soccer Program.

item.title: What to Expect at This Year's Holiday Concert
item.dc:creator: bacc
item.content:encoded:
We're just weeks away from our annual Holiday Celebration Service, which will combine dynamic entertainment with an inspiring message of hope in "The Power of Love" - think musical...think, A Christmas Carol. Our Children's Ministry will provide classes for kids up to four years old as well as Spiritual Resource Classes for children with special needs of all ages. We also offer "Santa's Playland," where kids can enjoy jump castles, slides, and other activities. Finally, join us in participating in our annual toy drive that donates hundreds of toys every year to foster care agencies across the Bay Area. Last year we were able to collect over 1,200 toys, and this year we hope to expand to reach more of the Bay Area as we continue to emphasize our commitment to community involvement. Last year's service brought us closer as a family, and we expect this year will be just as inviting as we gather home for the holidays. We hope this year's Holiday Service can be a memorable part of the holiday season for you and your family.

Details

What to expect:
  • BACC Orchestra Emsemble
  • Santa's Playland for the family
  • Annual Toy Drive
  • Spiritual Resource Ministry for kids of all ages
  • Children's Ministry for 0-4 years of age
  • Musical Excerpts performed from "A Christmas Carol: The Musical"
  • Traditional Christmas music for everyone to sing
What to know:
  • When: December 16, 3pm (note the later start time!)
  • Where: Santa Clara Convention Center

item.title: 5 Ways to Prevent the Flu this Season
item.dc:creator: mikequery
item.content:encoded:
MSNBC recently put out an article reporting  this year's flu season is early and accelerating. We want everyone to enjoy a flu free and prosperous new year.   The Center for Disease Control recommends the flu vaccine (please consult your physician before hand). The following are 5 daily preventative actions you can take to make sure that the flu does not interrupt yours or your friends plans and goals for the new year:
  • Wash your hands frequently throughout the day. Use an alcohol based hand rub if soap and water are unavailable.
  • Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth.  Germs spread this way
  • Cover your nose and mouth with tissue when you cough or sneeze. Throw away the tissue immediately
  • Avoid sick people
  • If you have flu like symptoms stay home until 24 hours after symptoms have passed.  (Fever should be gone with out the use of fever reducing medicines)
item.excerpt:encoded: Let's do our part to keep the flu away from ourselves, our friends and our family.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: 5 Ways to Prevent the Flu this Season

item.title: New Years Resolution: Don't Text and Drive
item.dc:creator: stone
item.content:encoded: The good people over at Detext have managed to put together a basic and rather helpful infographic that speaks to one of the biggest fears parents have for their teenagers: texting and driving. The thought of their kids texting or checking Facebook while on the road is enough to make even the strongest of parents feel dizzy. If you're a parent, and you take time to make one New Years resolution this year, consider making it this one. With harrowing statistics such as 77% of teens being confident that they can safely text while driving, it's safe to say that the technology they're proposing on their site could not come too soon. Check out the infographic below and start considering what you can do to make sure your kids are driving safely.

item.title: Boosting Your Immune System: How Antioxidants Help
item.dc:creator: bacc
item.content:encoded:
With the early arrival of the flu season one of the greatest preventative measures we can take is boosting our immune system.  The stronger our immune system the better chance of fighting off the flu as well as other diseases and bugs that can disrupt our lives. We've heard a lot about anti-oxidants and its health benefits. So why are eating these foods good for your body? Anti-oxidants repair the body’s cells when damaged by free radicals. The damaging of cells may lead to chronic diseases, arthritis and cancer and it also interferes with your immune system. So eating antioxidant rich foods boots your immune system making your body equipped to fight off colds, flu, and other infections. In an immune systems related article posted on WebMD, Kimball Johnson, MD lists the three major antioxidant vitamins are beta-carotene, vitamin C, and vitamin E. To get the biggest benefits of antioxidants, eat these foods raw or lightly steamed; don’t overcook or boil.
  1. Beta-carotene and other carotenoids: Apricots, asparagus, beets, broccoli, cantaloupe, carrots, corn, green peppers, kale, mangoes, turnip and collard greens, nectarines, peaches, pink grapefruit, pumpkin, squash, spinach, sweet potato, tangerines, tomatoes, and watermelon
  2. Vitamin C: Berries, broccoli, Brussels sprouts, cantaloupe, cauliflower, grapefruit, honeydew, kale, kiwi, mangoes, nectarines, orange, papaya, red, green or yellow peppers, snow peas, sweet potato, strawberries, and tomatoes
  3. Vitamin E: Broccoli, carrots, chard, mustard and turnip greens, mangoes, nuts, papaya, pumpkin, red peppers, spinach, and sunflower seeds
Other super foods that are rich in antioxidants include: Prunes, apples, raisins, all berries, plums, red grapes, alfalfa sprouts, onions, eggplant, beans. Other antioxidants that may help boost immunity include:
  • Zinc: Found in oysters, red meat, poultry, beans, nuts, seafood, whole grains, fortified cereals, and dairy products
  • Selenium: Found in Brazil nuts, tuna, beef, poultry and fortified breads, and other grain products
For further reading, check out USA today's diet and nutrition article highlighting different steps you can take to fight the flu and boost your immune system.
item.excerpt:encoded: Fight the flu this season by choosing the right food and vitamins

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Boosting Your Immune System: How Antioxidants Help
Fight the flu this season by choosing the right food and vitamins

With the early arrival of the flu season one of the greatest preventative measures we can take is boosting our immune system. The stronger our immune system the better chance of fighting off the flu as well as other diseases and bugs that can disrupt our lives.

item.title: 20 Great Date Ideas for Under $20
item.dc:creator: bacc
item.content:encoded:
Dating is a fun and important way for single professionals to meet and build relationships.  Unfortunately dating can be a source of angst as many professionals search for the secret to a great date.  It helpful to many to know that a successful date is less about the activity and more about the interactions on the date. "Try to make your date feel special. This doesn’t have to be achieved through bouquets of flowers and surprise gifts. The best way to charm somebody is by genuinely being interested in them. If you show that you care, and open yourself up, you should find that banishing those initial fears is much easier than you first imagined." Source: "How to Make and Impression on the First Date" Dating is a great opportunity to get to know someone better. It does not have to be elaborate or expensive.  It merely needs to provide a great environment that allows for opportunities to show an interest in the other person. With our upcoming professionals retreat entitled "Open Your Eyes" right around the corner, we thought it'd be fitting to provide you with some dating ideas that help provide opportunity with out financial worry. You can choose any of these options and have a blast with friends, building memories with someone without having to break the bank.  Maybe we can start a trend that will be popular and successful. 20 great date ideas...all for under $20!
  1. Game night - Grab your favorite board/card games and decide who's hosting. Toss in some change for snacks, and you've got yourself an evening filled with fun.
  2. Frisbee golf - If you haven't heard of this game, check out the basic components needed to get started, watch some tutorial videos, then have at it!
  3. Take a Hike - Stanford Dish, Muir Woods, and Coyote Point are all Bay Area hiking favorites.
  4. Cooking Night - Pool your money together for some basic ingredients, and get creative in the kitchen. Fun cooking together, fun eating together.
  5. Ping Pong Tournament - Get competitive with your date, or team up to compete against a worthy doubles opponent.
  6. Billiards - 8 ball, 9 ball, cut throat...they all work, and provide a great way to converse without the anxiety that can come with an expensive dinner.
  7. Hit the local music scene - The Bay Area has produced some of the most legendary music artists the world has seen (Journey, Grateful Dead, Train, E-40, Green Day, Metallica, MC Hammer, The Doobie Brothers...I'm getting carried away here), and they all had to start somewhere. Search the message boards and telephone poles for local band shows (often free or cheap), or check out any of the free music events taking place in the Bay any given weekend.
  8. Exploring - How far can you drive on a $10 tank of gas? Make sure to plan for the return trip.
  9. Froyo or Boba - Two popular Bay Area treats include froyo and Boba drinks. Take a trip down just about any main street (particularly on the Penninsula and South Bay), and you'll find a great spot to grab a treat and relax for a bit.
  10. Catch a Matinee - Spend a fraction of the price of a regular evening movie ticket and catch a flick with friends during the day. Be shocked as you exit the theatre to the odd sensation of daylight seeping through your eyelids as you exit the theatre...an experience to remember together.
  11. Skating/bike riding - The Bay is host to plenty of biking trails, as well as fun places to skateboard (just make sure you don't get kicked out of whichever establishment you deem best fit for skating, though that may provide a classic date memory). Date can't ride or skate? Even better! Study up and make it a teaching date.
  12. Beach bonfire - Grab some wood, some s'mores, and a guitar, and you've got yourself an entire evening of fun and memories. Make sure to bring a sweater.
  13. Scavenger hunt - Create a list of creative objects to find, pictures to take, and adventurous actions to check off a list. You can split your date group into teams and compete for the glory.
  14. Flea market - Hunt for fun items, then plan the rest of the evening around them. Be creative, see what you can come up with.
  15. Costco run - Assuming you have a friend with a membership, start your group at the entrance of your local Costco and make your way through the store, stopping by each food sample booth for a shameless free meal. After you've made a full loop, restart at the entrance and try another go. It may be (unbelievably) cheap, but what better way to tell if your date appreciates the real you? (Note: if you start dating steady, this is not a date you'll want to repeat).
  16. Theatre dress rehearsal - Often times, local theatres will offer tickets to the dress rehearsal of their show for a fraction of the cost of the regular ticket. Make some calls if you have a taste for the stage!
  17. Dessert for dinner - Similar to the cooking date, but strictly with desserts. Be creative!
  18. Babysit - Parents are always looking for opportunities to get a night out. Offer up your services, and spend the night entertaining the little one(s) and each other.
  19. Study date - Applies to high school and college students. Make a group date out of your finals cramming for some much needed morale boosting.
  20. Community service - Nothing brings people together quite like service. Find a way to incorporate volunteering into your date night for some positive memories.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Affordable ways to have a blast and build new relationships

Dating is a fun and important way for single professionals to meet and build relationships. Unfortunately dating can be a source of angst as many professionals search for the secret to a great date. item.title: Open Your Eyes: Why It's Important to Step Into the Light
item.dc:creator: mikequery
item.content:encoded:
Being open and honest about your life is an important first step towards becoming aware and becoming known. However, awareness alone is not enough. If you want to live a transformative life, you'll need to be willing to step into the light. Why is it important to step into the light?

Coram Deo

Blessed are those who have learned to acclaim you, who walk in the light of your presence, O Lord. Psalm 89:15-24 (NIV)
Coram is a Latin phrase that translates "in the presence of God." It's a concept that embodies the idea that as disciples, our main goal should be to live in such a way as to be in a close relationship with God, unlike any other we have on earth. Stepping into the light is about a desire to be close to God. It's not about whether or not you read your Bible or prayed today, or whether or not you were a good person. Being in God's presence means you understand and display the righteous fear, honor, & gratitude to be before his awesomeness. Imagine meeting your hero for the first time, in real life. Whether it's the pro athlete you've looked up to since you were a kid, or the movie star who's every film you've memorized ..that same sense of awe and speechlessness is the feeling that transpires when you're truly in the presence of God. The Honor to be in God’s Presence
Tremble, O earth, at the presence of the Lord, at the presence of the God of Jacob, [8] who turned the rock into a pool, the hard rock into springs of water. Psalm 114:7-8 (NIV)
The Shelter of God’s Presence
How abundant are the good things that you have stored up for those who fear you, that you bestow in the sight of all, on those who take refuge in you. [20] In the shelter of your presence you hide them from all human intrigues; you keep them safe in your dwelling from accusing tongues Psalm 31:19-20 (NIV)
The Joy of God’s Presence
They ate and drank with great joy in the presence of the Lord that day.... 1 Chronicles 29:22 (NIV)

The Power of God's Presence

When you're in the presence of God, it changes who you are. Take the example of Moses who, prior to spending time with God, was timid and afraid, and used whatever excuse he could do get out of doing something big.
When Moses came down from Mount Sinai with the two tablets of the covenant law in his hands, he was not aware that his face was radiant because he had spoken with the Lord. [30] When Aaron and all the Israelites saw Moses, his face was radiant, and they were afraid to come near him. [33] When Moses finished speaking to them, he put a veil over his face. [34] But whenever he entered the Lord’s presence to speak with him, he removed the veil until he came out. And when he came out and told the Israelites what he had been commanded, [35] they saw that his face was radiant. Then Moses would put the veil back over his face until he went in to speak with the Lord. Exodus 34:29-30,33-35 (NIV)
The change was noticeable when Moses spent time with God, so much so that the Israelites were in a fearful awe whenever he'd come out of his times with God. It was obvious to them that Moses walked with God, and they were careful not to rub him the wrong way. The Bible teaches us that this type of transformation can be experienced by anyone, even today:
16 But whenever anyone turns to the Lord, the veil is taken away. 17 Now the Lord is the Spirit, and where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is freedom. 18 And we all, who with unveiled faces contemplate the Lord’s glory, are being transformed into his image with ever-increasing glory, which comes from the Lord, who is the Spirit. 2 Corinthians 3:16-18 (NIV)
Spending time with God today leads to a radical transformation; there's nothing that can't be changed when you're in God's presence. It means overcoming sin, addictions, or relationship damage, or transforming from selfish to empathetic, bitter and hard-hearted to considerate, or proud to humble. There's no substitute and nothing like putting in time to be with God. So how do we accomplish this? What does it take to make the time we spend with God worthwhile  and as powerful as Moses'?

The Choice

There's a choice we face every day we're alive: the choice between God and sin. There's a conflict that exists for those of us who try and have both, because it's not possible to be in God's presence and also value sin, since God is, in essence, the absence of sin.
Should you not fear me?” declares the Lord. “Should you not tremble in my presence? I made the sand a boundary for the sea, an everlasting barrier it cannot cross. The waves may roll, but they cannot prevail; they may roar, but they cannot cross it. [23] But these people have stubborn and rebellious hearts; they have turned aside and gone away. [24] They do not say to themselves, ‘Let us fear the Lord our God, who gives autumn and spring rains in season, who assures us of the regular weeks of harvest.’ [25] Your wrongdoings have kept these away; your sins have deprived you of good. [26] “Among my people are the wicked who lie in wait like men who snare birds and like those who set traps to catch people. [27] Like cages full of birds, their houses are full of deceit... Jeremiah 5:22-27 (NIV)
When you desire darkness, you've become a churchgoer, and not someone who lives in the Kingdom of God. Church is a Sunday service, a midweek service, or a devotional. The Kingdom is something you live in 24/7. It's an important distinction to make, because we can fool ourselves into thinking we're in the presence of God because our physical presence is in a seemingly spiritual place. However, the love of darkness is something that will undo us in the end. Hidden and unrepented sin is what leads to this confusion. If you're someone who is engaging in immorality, drunkenness, bitterness, or other relationship damaging sins and not talking about it with anyone, you're sabotaging your ability to be in the presence of God. Your idea of God becomes church attendance, and it's not long before you make the decision that it's not worth it to keep up the facade.

The Way Out

Create in me a pure heart, O God, and renew a steadfast spirit within me. [11] Do not cast me from your presence or take your Holy Spirit from me. [12] Restore to me the joy of your salvation and grant me a willing spirit, to sustain me. [13] Then I will teach transgressors your ways, and sinners will turn back to you. [14] Save me from bloodguilt, O God, the God who saves me, and my tongue will sing of your righteousness. [15] O Lord, open my lips, and my mouth will declare your praise. [16] You do not delight in sacrifice, or I would bring it; you do not take pleasure in burnt offerings. [17] The sacrifices of God are a broken spirit; a broken and contrite heart... Psalm 51:10-17 (NIV)
Confession is something personal to God. It's not just the process unloading everything you feel guilty of, but rather agreeing with God about your sin and it's affect on Him and other relationships. It's understanding the damage done, and being adamant about making it right. It's about clearing your conscience, because it causes distance in relationships when there's something inside you're holding back. If you've found yourself in a spot where you're physically at everything imaginable but don't feel any closer to God or still feel guilty and weighed down, the answer is to ask for a new heart and to return to God's presence. Remember how refreshing and transformative an experience it is to be in God's presence, and make the decision today to unload anything and everything that you've been keeping locked up inside so that you be freed up and on your way to a new life.
