item.title: Expo Class Notes Now Available
item.dc:creator: mikequery
item.content:encoded:
Access Class Notes Every year our annual Expo, folks do the best they can to make every class they set out to attend. However, we understand that due to issues both foreseen and unforeseen, many people still are unable to make every class they set out to attend. It's for this reason that this year, we are making class notes available online for every class taught at our 2012 Expo. The class notes are structured in the following format, to help keep things cohesive in case you need to view multiple classes:
  • Purpose/Introduction - A brief (1-3 sentences) summary that explains why this class was taught, and who it's intended for.
  • Scriptures - The main/theme scripture(s) for the class. There were obviously many used in each class, but these are the primary ones that set the tone.
  • 3 Main Ideas - Each class can be broken up into 3 main ideas that explain the topic in an easily digestible format. Each idea typically has a scripture, and some points to go with them.
  • Question/Application - You can use these to take what you've learned with you into the real world.
  • Additional Reading - Supplemental reading that will help you expand on what you've learned from this class. Sometimes these are specific scriptures, books of the Bible, or in some cases outside reading that can be purchased at Amazon or your local bookstore.
We hope these class notes are helpful, and allow you to take what you soaked in over the Expo weekend and build convictions that last the rest of the year and beyond.

item.title: Inspired to Lead
item.dc:creator: bnitta
item.content:encoded:
Purpose/introduction

  • God’s Kingdom is meant to be family.
  • Family is experienced through the house church.
  • Family is only built through close relationships (intimacy).
  • Intimacy is created through the 5 senses.

5 Main Ideas

1. The Sense of HEARING: Does God’s Voice Guide you? Isaiah 50:4-5 NIV
  • Who’s voice do you hear loudest?
  • Do you allow God’s voice to guide you?
2. The Sense of SIGHT: Are Your Sights Set on God? 1 Kings 17:2-7 CEV
  • Do you see God when challenging times happen…in the middle of a drought?
  • When people are around you do they gain sight of God or lose sight of God?
3. The Sense of TASTE: Do you experience God when you spend time with him? Psalm 63:1-5NLT
  • Where do you go to find satisfaction?
  • Is God the source of your joy?
4. The Sense of TOUCH: Are there areas of your life that are untouchable? John 13:1-8 NIV
  • Do you allow Jesus to touch every part of your life?
  • Are there parts of your friends lives that you are unwilling to touch on?
  • Unless you’re willing to touch someone’s life, you can’t change their life.
5. The Sense of SMELL: What will you sacrifice for family? John 11:33-40 NIV
  • Jesus was willing to endure the bad odor to raise Lazarus to life.
  • You cannot raise back to life any areas of one’s life if you refuse to sacrifice to be close them.

Questions/Applications

Our level of intimacy with God will determine the level of intimacy we will have with relationships in our HC. How close are the relationships in your HC based on the 5 senses described here:
  • Do your relationships help you to hear God?
  • Do your relationships focus you on God or on others?
  • Do your relationships genuinely enjoy spending time together?
  • Are there any areas “off limits” that your relationships do not go with each other?
  • Are there sacrifices made to develop a sense of family in your relationships?

Additional Reading

Study the Gospel of John and take note of the ways Jesus developed intimacy among his close relationships: the 3, the 12, and 72.

item.title: Why Success Always Starts With Failure
item.dc:creator: ahenderson
item.content:encoded:
Purpose

The goal is to help us understand that we have a skewed view of what failure is. What we see as failure, God sees as training and molding us into who we’re meant to become. We all fail at something; the key is learning to get more strength from God. What makes our lives relevant is that God can use us to change lives.

Scriptures

Luke 16:15, Genesis 12:1-4, Genesis 15:1-6, Genesis 18:10-15, Genesis 21:1-7, Hosea 10:12, Proverbs 17:17, Proverbs 11:25, Ecclesiastes 4:9-10, Luke 15:28-32, James 5:1-3, John 12:42-43, Matthew 6:22, Proverbs 24:16, Psalm 18:32-33, Psalm 18:28

3 Main Ideas

Idea 1: God always keeps his promise Genesis 12:1-3 NLT - The LORD had said to Abram, “Leave your native country, your relatives, and your father’s family, and go to the land that I will show you. 2 I will make you into a great nation. I will bless you and make you famous, and you will be a blessing to others. 3 I will bless those who bless you and curse those who treat you with contempt. All the families on earth will be blessed through you.”
  • God makes a promise to Abram, that he will fulfill years later
  • Abram had to go through a process, embrace “failure”, but through it all, still make a decision to believe in God’s promise
  • God’s promise always comes, on his timing. We need to learn the lessons he wants us to along the way and not get impatient.
Idea 2: Friendships find faith Hosea 10:12 NLT - “I said, ‘Plant the good seeds of righteousness, and you will harvest a crop of love. Plow up the hard ground of your hearts, for now is the time to seek the Lord, that he may come and shower righteousness upon you.”
  • Spiritual friends bring truth
  • Going through different difficulties in our lives can have us doubt God’s love and protection, nevertheless, relationships are there to guide us to the right path and get us to where God wants to take us
  • We build our own convictions when we help others
  • Friendships help us hold on to faith
Idea 3: How do we lose our faith? Overcoming the Religion of Me Luke 15:28-32 NLT - 28 “The older brother was angry and wouldn’t go in. His father came out and begged him,29but he replied, ‘All these years I’ve slaved for you and never once refused to do a single thing you told me to. And in all that time you never gave me even one young goat for a feast with my friends. 30 Yet when this son of yours comes back after squandering your money on prostitutes, you celebrate by killing the fattened calf!’31 “His father said to him, ‘Look, dear son, you have always stayed by me, and everything I have is yours. 32 We had to celebrate this happy day. For your brother was dead and has come back to life! He was lost, but now he is found!’”
  • I deserve because I serve: Bitter and Ungrateful heart
  • Switching our motivation from self to God
  • Finding relevance with God

Questions

  • What promises has God made us that we let go of?
  • Do we see truth as encouraging?
  • What makes us relevant?
  • What makes us lose our faith?
  • Admit when our desires have nothing to do with God

item.title: Start With "Why"
item.dc:creator: dhowell
item.content:encoded:
Purpose/Introduction

To help all of us understand “why” we must hold onto our faith in God when life’s purpose isn’t clear. How do I stay faithful when I can’t see what God is doing?

Scripture

1 Peter 1:6-7 (NIV) “In this you greatly rejoice though now for a little while you may have had to suffer grief in all kinds of trials. These have come so that your faith – of greater worth than gold, which perishes even though refined by fire – may be proved genuine and may result in praise, glory and honor when Jesus Christ is revealed.”

3 Main Ideas

Idea 1: “Waiting For God” Proverbs 2:3-5 (NLT) - My child, listen to what I say and treasure my commands. Tune your ears to wisdom, and concentrate on understanding. Cry out for insight, and ask for understanding. Search for them as you would for silver; seek them like hidden treasures. Then you will understand what it means to fear the LORD, and you will gain knowledge of God.” Our most recent journey has been waiting for our son to decide to become a Christian. I don’t know if my faith has ever been tested so much; and if I have ever felt such emotional pain, anguish, discouragement, fear, bitterness – so much came out of my heart during the waiting! The feeling that there is nothing you can really do; we had to change our whole lives, but there was no guarantee that any changes we made would have any effect on him. I did not know that this would be one of my greatest tests and we have had many others! We have a kid with special needs, we have been in and out of the ministry, we have moved a few times, we have been robbed; to name a few! We all have been through things in our lives! Idea 2: “Waiting With Friends” Acts 2:42-44 (ESV) - 42 And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers. 43 And awe[a] came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles. 44 And all who believed were together and had all things in common. I recall three significant moments where I was bitter because of my circumstances feeling entitled to more, or better, or an easier way in life only to be confronted by some of the most improbable people to tell me painful truths about my character: that I was a blame shifter, playing the victim, shirking my responsibilities as a husband, father, and friend. Each one of these men, my friends, my brothers looked me in the eye and told me hard truths about myself I would have never accepted on my own. Each one of these men made a commitment to God first to speak the truth in love, to not back down when faced w/ rebellious, rage-ful, obstinate, men like myself. And I’m eternally grateful to their faithfulness to God then to me.

Idea 3: “Why Me?"

Romans 8:26 – “In the same way, the Spirit helps us in our weakness. We do not know what we ought to pray for, but the Spirit himself intercedes for us with groans that words cannot express.” In my relationship with God, it went from expressing my hopes and dreams and desires to God, to becoming a silent time. I would close my eyes to pray and all I could pray was for the spirit to pray for me. The picture in my mind was God sitting on his throne with me sitting at his feet with no words between us. I pictured myself looking up just to make sure He was still there.

Questions/Application

  • How do you keep your faith when you want something so badly but not sure that it’s what God wants?
  • How do we reconcile knowing that God can do anything, but wondering whether he will actually do what we ask?
  • How do we figure out what we are actually supposed to believe?
  • Are you willing to pray that radical prayer “God do whatever it takes?”
  • Are you willing to let go and God do whatever He has to do for your kids to become Christians?

Additional Reading

  • Jeremiah 29:11
  • Proverbs 19:20-22 (MSG)
  • Luke 14:25-27
  • Luke 22:30-32
  • Ecclesiastes 7:26-29
  • Galatians 5:16-18 (MSG)

item.title: The Big Shift
item.dc:creator: dmotamed
item.content:encoded:
Purpose/Introdution

This class will help you transform from the inside out into someone who values God and people (intrinsic motivation) over yourself and looking good (extrinsic motivation).

Scripture

Matthew 9: 35-36 - 35 Jesus went through all the towns and villages, teaching in their synagogues, preaching the good news of the kingdom and healing every disease and sickness. 36 When he saw the crowds, he had compassion on them, because they were harassed and helpless, like sheep without a shepherd. Idea 1: Chosen or Competitive 1 Peter 2:9 (Chosen) - However, you are chosen people, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, people who belong to God. You were chosen to tell about the excellent qualities of God, who called you out of darkness into his marvelous light.
  • When you believe that God has hand-picked you to be close to Him and do great things, you won’t have time to compare yourself with others and be competitive/jealous with them.
Idea 2: Depth or Disconnected John 11:32-37 (Depth) - 32When Mary reached the place where Jesus was and saw him, she fell at his feet and said, “Lord, if you had been here, my brother would not have died.” 33When Jesus saw here weeping, and the Jews who had come along with her also weeping, he was deeply moved in spirit and troubled. 34”Where have you laid him?” he asked. “Come and see, Lord,” they replied. 35Jesus wept. 36Then the Jews said, “See how he loved him!”
  • When you decide to be honest about your emotions and motives, you attach to people and create depth in your relationships. However, when you focus on looking and feeling good, you actually disconnect from people because no one ends up knowing who you really are.
Idea 3: Taking Charge or Taking Orders Isaiah 50:7 (Taking Charge) - Because the Sovereign Lord helps me, I will not be disgraced. Therefore, I have set my face like a stone, determined to do his will. And I know that I will not be put to shame.
  • It isn’t good enough to just do things because they are right, that just leads to frustration. Life is best when you’re passionate about what you do and when you take charge.

Questions

  • What member of your family do you need to have more compassion on?
  • What is one good thing you can learn from a friend? What is something positive you bring to your friendships?
  • What is one truth about yourself that you have been ignoring?
  • How can you change to take charge in your relationships?

Additional Reading

  • Luke 11:42-43 (Consumed)
  • Isaiah 58:10-11 (Compassionate)
  • Luke 7:30 (Competitive)
  • Luke 5:30-33 (Disconnected)
  • Luke 11:39-41 (Taking Orders)
  • Compare and contrast David and Moses (intrinsic) vs. Saul and Pharaoh (extrinsic) in I Samuel and Exodus
item.excerpt:encoded: What's Motivating You? (Teens and campus)

item.title: Building Spiritual Awareness
item.dc:creator: rkim
item.content:encoded:
Purpose/Introduction

One of the greatest barriers to building an intimate relationship with God is our fear of being known. When we overcome this fear, we develop a security with God that enables us to be ourselves, genuinely love others and build transformative friendships. This begins with building spiritual awareness of our heart condition, our motives (intrinsic vs. extrinsic) and our view of God.

Scripture

Psalm 139:1-5 (NLT) - 1 O LORD, you have examined my heart and know everything about me. 2 You know when I sit down or stand up. You know my thoughts even when I’m far away. 3 You see me when I travel and when I rest at home. You know everything I do. 4 You know what I am going to say even before I say it, LORD. 5 You go before me and follow me. You place your hand of blessing on my head.

4 Main Ideas: Understanding the 4 Sides of Our Heart

1) The Open Side (vs. 19 You know the commandments…) Mark 10:17-19 (NLT) - 17 As Jesus was starting out on his way to Jerusalem, a man came running up to him, knelt down, and asked, “Good Teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?” 18 “Why do you call me good?” Jesus asked. “Only God is truly good. 19 But to answer your question, you know the commandments: ‘You must not murder. You must not commit adultery. You must not steal. You must not testify falsely. You must not cheat anyone. Honor your father and mother.’”
  • The Opens Side - this is the part of our hearts that consists of who we are that is known by both us and others; it’s easily recognizable to all and includes our physical characteristics (ethnicity, life-point, age, school, career interests) and our outward temperament, personalities, our likes and dislikes
  • It was clear that this man who approached Jesus was both religious, accomplished, and outwardly humble, but spiritually unaware
2) The Blind Side (vs. 20 – I’ve obeyed all…) Mark 10:20 (NLT) - 20 “Teacher,” the man replied, “I’ve obeyed all these commandments since I was young.”
  • The Blind Side - this is the part of our hearts characterizing who we are that is known to others, but in we are personally blind and in denial about. When we’re too busy flattering ourselves, we can’t detect or hate the sin that keeps us distant from God and others (Ps. 36:4). Choosing to discover truth rather than defend ourselves is key to drawing closer to God.
  • This man was focused on the outside (all that he had been doing right, his moral performance and rule-keeping since youth), but unaware of what was on the inside - his present heart condition - which was Jesus’ primary concern.
3) The Concealed Side (vs. 22 – …he went away sad) Mark 10:21-22 - 21 Looking at the man, Jesus felt genuine love for him. “There is still one thing you haven’t done,” he told him. “Go and sell all your possessions and give the money to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. Then come, follow me.” 22 At this the man’s face fell, and he went away sad, for he had many possessions.
  • The Concealed Side - this is the aspect of ourselves which we actually know inside, but choose not to reveal to God or others outside. We deliberately choose to keep details of our lives, desires, and attachments concealed. Lacking security and trust in God, we work hard to hide our fears, hopes, dreams from others because we suspect that any of these maybe unaccepted, belittled, unappreciated, ridiculed, or negatively by people. We take great pains to keep these concealed, causing anxiety, stress, and eventual sadness, despite God’s genuine love for us.
  • What this man didn’t want to face or admit was that his attachment to the things of the world (1 John 2:15-17), was greater than his attachment to God.
4) The Unknown Side (vs. 21 – there is still one thing)
  • The Unknown Side - this is the part of us that neither we nor others are aware of. As a result, nobody – including us—understands the roots of our impulses or motivation, why we feel the way we feel or act, or make the choices we make. We’re at a loss and completely unaware and unable to explain our hearts, yet that unknown fact has an impact on who we are and what we do, and only God alone knows this deepest part of who we are at our core, and therefore this why apart from him we’ll always be insecure. God makes what’s unknown about our hearts, known.
  • Jesus knew what no one else knew about this rich young man’s heart – he didn’t have the faith to trust God completely with is life – that his fear of going without trumped his faith in God alone being enough. He was seemingly content in following all the rules, not realizing that it covered up a deep unbelief that kept him from loving God.

Questions/Application

  • Which of the 4 Areas of my Heart am I most unaware of?
  • What am I attached to more than God – my emotional priority?
  • Do I feel close to God, my spouse? My friends? Why or Why Not?
  • How has my Heart Condition influenced my view of God?

Additional Reading/Prayer Ideas:

  • Download this Quiet Time packet to continue on this topic
item.excerpt:encoded: Knowing God – Overcoming the fear of being known, so we become secure in God, and secure with people.

item.title: Spiritual Conversations
item.dc:creator: skiluk
item.content:encoded:
Purpose/Introduction

The purpose of this class is to teach how to help any conversation to be a spiritual conversation. Although it may seem simple, some of us need to go the great lengths to have an honest conversation:

5 Steps to Having Spiritual Conversations: S-P-E-A-K

S hare In Life 1 John 1:5-7 (CEV) - Jesus told us that God is light and doesn’t have any darkness in him. Now we are telling you. 6 If we say that we share in life with God and keep on living in the dark, we are lying and are not living by the truth. 7 But if we live in the light, as God does, we share in life with each other. And the blood of his Son Jesus washes all our sins away.
  • Fellowship is about sharing life with each other, not just talking. To have a spiritual conversation, you need to share a part of your life with someone.
P ay Attention to Your Heart Luke 6:45 (Easy-to-Read Version) - Good people have good things saved in their hearts. That’s why they say good things. But those who are evil have hearts full of evil, and that’s why they say things that are evil. What people say with their mouths comes from what fills their hearts.
  • Without paying attention to your heart, your conversations will lack depth.
E njoy Friendship Hebrews 3:12-13 (NLT) - Be careful then, dear brothers and sisters. Make sure that your own hearts are not evil and unbelieving, turning you away from the living God. [13] You must warn each other every day, while it is still "today," so that none of you will be deceived by sin and hardened against God.
  • Without enjoying your friends, you will not enjoy spiritual conversations. We all need them.
A sk God I Corinthians 2:13-15 (MSG) - We didn't learn this by reading books or going to school; we learned it from God, who taught us person-to-person through Jesus, and we're passing it on to you in the same firsthand, personal way. The unspiritual self, just as it is by nature, can't receive the gifts of God's Spirit. There's no capacity for them. They seem like so much silliness. Spirit can be known only by spirit—God's Spirit and our spirits in open communion. Spiritually alive, we have access to everything God's Spirit is doing, and can't be judged by unspiritual critics.
  • God puts the spiritual into the conversation.
  • Without God, we are just not the same, just like Snickers.
K ick Into Gear 1 John 3:18 (NIV) - Dear children, let us not love with words or speech but with actions and in truth.
  • Take some action. Set your mind to have some spiritual conversations today!

Questions/Application

  • What insecurities do you have that hold you back from sharing your life?
  • Has something happened in past conversations that make you not want to be honest?
  • What sins are being exposed in conversations you are having? (bitterness, envy, etc)
  • What friendships do you not enjoy? Why not? Is there pride you need to let go of?
  • Who can you have a spiritual conversation with today?

Additional Reading

  • 1 & 2 Thessalonians
  • 1 John
  • Philippians

item.title: Finding Happiness
item.dc:creator: jcoulliette
item.content:encoded:
Purpose/Introduction

Learn to value relationships and find happiness in making attachments that create lasting joy. Key Thought: There are 4 Relationships that we need to focus on attaching to.
  1. Attaching to God
  2. Attaching in the Home
  3. Attaching to Our Kids
  4. Attaching to Our Friends

Scripture

1 Corinthians 16:18 (Worldwide English) - They have made me happy and you also. Show that you know the value of such men.

4 Main Ideas

1. You Know All About Me (Attaching to God) 2 Timothy 3:10 - But you know all about my teaching. You know how I live and what I live for. You know about my faith and love. In the face of life’s challenges, we often choose to avoid the truth by turning to comfort & denial, but these make us distant & detached in our relationships and marriages. We end up hurting those who God put in our life to help us most. Sharing with God & other people about our suffering is how God helps us to be close, but when we turn to comfort & denial, we miss out on being close. 2. I Hold You in My Heart (Attaching in the Home) Philippians 1:6-7 AMP - 6 And I am convinced and sure of this very thing, that He Who began a good work in you will continue until the day of Jesus Christ [right up to the time of His return], developing [that good work] and perfecting and bringing it to full completion in you. 7 It is right and appropriate for me to have this confidence and feel this way about you all, because you have me in your heart and I hold you in my heart. When we live like our performance is how we are accepted by people, we do not let people know we need them or their help. We need our spouse to help us understand who we are and help understand what we are feeling. As we understand who we are, we can turn to God together and rely on him to persevere through life’s challenges, and build each other’s faith that God is going to do something special as he carries us through. 3. Nothing will Separate Us (Attaching to Our Kids) Ruth 1:16-17 - 16 But Ruth replied, “Don’t urge me to leave you or to turn back from you. Where you go I will go, and where you stay I will stay. Your people will be my people and your God my God. 17 Where you die I will die, and there I will be buried. May the Lord deal with me, be it ever so severely, if even death separates you and me.” Be vulnerable and emotionally honest with our kids. Share with them the challenges, painful experiences, and the joyful experiences with them. Let them know how much you need God’s help through life. Ask them for their help and insights. 4. The True Spirit of Humility (Attaching to Our Friends) Philippians 2:4-5 AMP - 4 Let each of you esteem and look upon and be concerned for not [merely] his own interests, but also each for the interests of others. 5 Let this same attitude and purpose and [humble] mind be in you which was in Christ Jesus: [Let Him be your example in humility] Change the way we interact with people. Competitiveness and cowardice are both rooted in pride and consumed with ourselves. Turn to God & consider what other people have been through and are going through. Learn from them and ask about what they need in order to help them and work together through life’s ups and downs.

Questions/Applications

1. What are unspiritual attachments I make? What sins has this led to that hurt relationships? How have these impacted my relationships? (see chart)   2. Who is one person that I need to attach to? When will you spend time and tell them how much you need them? Decide and express to them that you will be truthful with them when you face challenges, so you can help one another to be faithful through ups and downs.
item.excerpt:encoded: Learn to value relationships and find happiness in making attachments that create lasting joy.

item.title: The Road to Change
item.dc:creator: rkim
item.content:encoded:
This article is the first in a series called "Changed 2012," which are meant to give context and insight to prepare you for our upcoming Professionals' Retreat entitled "Changed." Everyday, we have a choice to change the world or be changed by it. Jesus was a catalyst of change wherever he went and for whomever he was with. Are you a change-agent of the culture around you at your workplace, home, social network, or community?
Don’t become so well-adjusted to your culture that you fit into it without even thinking. Instead, fix your attention on God. You’ll be changed from the inside out. Romans 12:2
To be changed from the inside-out, we must first understand what change is:

Change Is...

  • Change is something that presses us out of our comfort zone. It is destiny-filtered, heart grown, faith built. Real change is intrinsically motivated, not extrinsic, sustained by conviction not dependent upon circumstance.
  • Change is for the better or for the worst, depending on where you view it.
  • Change has an adjustment period which varies on the individual. It is uncomfortable , for changing from one state to the next upsets our control over outcomes.
  • Change has a ripping effect on those who won’t let go. Flex is the key. Even a roller coaster ride can be fun if you know when to lean and create new balance within the change.
  • Change is needed when all the props and practices of the past no longer work.
  • Change is not comforted by the statement ‘just hang in there’ but with the statement ‘you can make it’. We don’t grow in retreat, but through endurance.
  • Change isn't fixed by crying, worrying, or mental treadmilling.
  • Change is won by victors not victims; and that choice is ours.
  • Change is awkward -- at first.
  • Change is a muscle that develops to abundantly enjoy the dynamics of the life set before us.
  • Change calls own strength beyond anyone of us.
  • Change pushes you to do your personal best.
  • Change draws out those poised for a new way.
  • Change isn’t for chickens.
  • Change does have casualties of those defeated.
  • Change will cause us to churn or to learn.
  • Change changes the speed of time. Time is so slow for the reluctant, and yet it is a whirlwind for those who embrace it.
  • Change is more fun to do than to be done to.
  • Change seeks a better place at the end and is complete when you realize you are different.
  • Change is measured by its impact on all who are connected to it.
  • Change is charged when you are dissatisfied with where you are.
  • Change doesn’t look for a resting-place; just the next launching point.
  • Change is only a waste to those who don’t learn from it.
  • Change happens in the heart before it is proclaimed by our works.
  • Change chaps those moving slower than the change itself. If you can change before you have to change, there will be less pain.
  • Change can flow or jerk, depending on our resistance to it.
  • Change uses the power invested in the unseen to reinvent what is seen. It takes faith, and God enables change.
  • Change is like driving in a fog – you can’t see very far, but Vision becomes clear after going through the change.
  • Change is here to stay. Are you ready to be CHANGED?
The 2012 Professionals Retreat (Sep 28-29) entitled “CHANGED”, you’ll discover how to experience personal change from the inside out in:
  1. Relationship with God
  2. Personal vision and clarity of purpose
  3. Dating relationships & marriage
  4. Building your career and network
  5. Having Impact in your Community/Workplace
Register for "CHANGED" today!

Change Is...

item.title: Did You Know? 6 Interesting Marriage Facts
item.dc:creator: smanuel
item.content:encoded:
Whether you're a newlywed, a veteran married couple, or an aspiring dating couple, it can be easy to forget just how unique and special marriage is. Oftentimes we get so caught up in the challenges and doldrums that we fail to see just how lucky we are to have what we have, and what it takes to keep the inspiring stuff in front of us.

As we approach our upcoming Marriage Refreshment Weekend entitled "Faithfully," let's take a look at 6 interesting facts about marriage that should keep things interesting until the refreshing begins:

A Source of Joy

Marriage does more to promote life satisfaction than money, sex, or even children, according to Wake Forest University psychologists.

It Takes Time to Connect

Due to jobs, kids, TV, the Internet, hobbies, and home and family responsibilities, the average married couple spends just four minutes a day alone together.

Our Heart Condition is Crucial

A 15-year-long study found that a person’s happiness level before marriage was the best predictor of happiness after marriage. In other words, marriage won’t automatically make one happy.

Affected by Financial Stress

CNN reports that the current economy is the biggest stress on married couples in the past 60 years. Try to find ways to make your finances a chore, and nothing more. Seek help from a financial advisor to determine a plan that will get you on the right track over time.

The Writing on the Wall

It's helpful to take a look at your and your spouse's past and upbringing to learn more about what we may feel tempted by or fearful of repeating. Research points to certain characteristics that are most often linked to infidelity, such as:

  • Being raised in a family where having affairs is considered normal
  • Having a personality that values excitement and risk taking over marital stability
  • Having coworkers and friends who believe affairs are acceptable
  • Feeling emotionally distant from one’s spouse.

Knowing is Half the Battle

Words form only 7% of our communication with anyone, including spouses. Tone of voice accounts for 38% and body language is responsible for 55% of the messages spouses receive from each other.

item.title: New "Faithfully" Bible Study Series: Intimate Relationships
item.dc:creator: bacc
item.content:encoded:
"I am the Vine, you are the branches. When you're joined with me and I with you, the relation intimate and organic, the harvest is sure to be abundant. Separated, you can't produce a thing. Anyone who separates from me is deadwood, gathered up and thrown on the bonfire. But if you make yourselves at home with me and my words are at home in you, you can be sure that whatever you ask will be listened to and acted upon. John 15:5-7 (MSG) God desires and created us to have close and intimate relationships. Intimacy starts in our relationship with God. If we cannot be close and love a God who is perfect we will not be able to be close and love imperfect people. Intimacy is a vital part of our growth as couples. We wither internally and will not grow without a close relationship with God and others. What does an intimate relationship with God and our spouse look like?
  • Intimacy: Interest - A desire to know and understand both God and our spouse’s heart & mind
  • Intimacy: Honesty - Open with your most personal and private thoughts, feelings and sins
  • Intimacy: Vulnerable - Invite God, our spouse and friends in to know and understand us (our feelings, pain, needs, desires)
  • Intimacy: Compassion - Allow ourselves to enter and share in the pain and suffering of God, our spouse and others
With our Marriage Refreshment Weekend coming up next month, we wanted to start a quiet time series entitled "Intimate Relationships" that will prepare you for what's to come. The studies focus on building an intimate relationship with God, which will allow and guide you to do the same with your spouse. You can check out Part One: "I Want to Know, Learn and Understand!" immediately. The rest of the series will be published between now and the retreat, which takes place November 2.

item.title: Intimate Relationships: I Want to Know, Learn, and Understand!
item.dc:creator: bacc
item.content:encoded:
This is the first in a series of Bible Studies entitled "Intimate Relationships." The studies explain how to develop an intimate relationship with your spouse by learning how to build one first with God.  Intimacy: Interest- A personal desire to know and understand the heart of God and our spouse I Chronicles 28:9 (NLT) - “And Solomon, my son, learn to know the God of your ancestors intimately. Worship and serve him with your whole heart and a willing mind. For the LORD sees every heart and knows every plan and thought. If you seek him, you will find him. But if you forsake him, he will reject you forever.  
  • God wants us to be interested in him and have a desire to know him.  Intimacy starts in our relationship with God.
  • Are you making time daily to “know” God? What He is doing in your life? How He feels? What He desires from you in your marriage?  What positive impact He wants your marriage to have on those around you?
  Philippians 2:1-3 - If you have any encouragement from being united with Christ, if any comfort from his love, if any fellowship with the Spirit, if any tenderness and compassion, 2 then make my joy complete by being like-minded, having the same love, being one in spirit and purpose. 3 Do nothing out of selfish ambition or vain conceit, but in humility consider others better than yourselves.  
  • Are you getting encouragement, comfort, fellowship and emotional resilience in your personal time with God?
  • Do you take time daily to ask God to help you have the emotional resilience to know & listen to your spouse?
 Mark 4:19 (NLT)  - ...but all too quickly the message is crowded out by the worries of this life, the lure of wealth, and the desire for other things, so no fruit is produced.
  •  What are the things that threaten or destroy intimacy in your relationship with God?
 Song of Songs 2:15 (NLT) - Catch all the foxes, those little foxes, before they ruin the vineyard of love, for the grapevines are blossoming!
  • What are the things in your heart that can ruin intimacy?  What are the things in your spouse’s heart that can ruin intimacy?
Song of Solomon 2:14 (NLT) - My dove is hiding behind the rocks, behind an outcrop on the cliff. Let me see your face; let me hear your voice. For your voice is pleasant, and your face is lovely.
  • How will you encourage more openness and honest conversations with your spouse?
Proverbs 20:5 - The purposes of a man’s heart are deep waters, but a man of understanding draws them out. Proverbs 14:29 - A person of great understanding is patient, but a short temper is the height of stupidity.
  • What stops you from listening and understanding your spouse’s heart?
 Proverbs 19:11 - A man’s wisdom gives him patience; it is to his glory to overlook an offense. Prayer Challenge:
  • I Peter 3:4-7
  • Decide you want intimacy with God and your spouse daily!

item.title: “Faithfully” Choosing Character
item.dc:creator: bacc
item.content:encoded:
This article is a part of a series of recaps from our recent Marriage Refreshment Weekend, which we’re calling “Faithfully: Class Notes.” We will continue to release these over the following week in order to give everyone a chance to revisit what they learned, and to give those who could not attend an opportunity to see what they missed.

Purpose/introduction

Our hearts and character have the greatest impact on our relationships and future. We have to keep our hearts inspired and strengthen our character to move beyond fear and take hold of the great things God wants to do with our lives.

Scripture

Until the time came to fulfill his dreams, the LORD tested Joseph’s character. Psalm 105:19 (NLT)

Idea 1: Be Inspired

Acts 17:11 - A 15-year-long study found that a person’s happiness level before marriage was the best predictor of happiness after marriage. In other words, marriage won’t automatically make one happy.

Idea 2: Emotional Resilience

Romans 5:3-5 - Fact= Women who report a fair division of housework were happier in their marriages than women who thought their husbands didn’t do their fair share. Wives also spent more quality time with their husbands when they thought the housework was divided fairly.

Idea 3: Friendship & Impact

Luke 11:5-10 & Genesis 44:5 - When we allow our challenges to build our character, it allows for greater impact on the relationships around us. God is always shaping our characters so that we can have the greatest possible impact in the lives of those around us.

Questions/Application

  1. What is an area of disappointment in your marriage that you have stopped talking about because you don’t believe it will change?
  2. How are you getting inspired through your Bible study and prayer to develop loving character?
  3. What are our greatest fears and doubts?
    1. Fear of failure - Not good enough
    2. Fear of rejection - Left out, dismissed and alone
    3. Fear of being controlled - Taken advantage of
    4. Fear of conflict - Abuse or harm
    5. Fear of being known - Misunderstood or judged
  4. Who are the 5 relationships that can help you face the fears that stop you from building loving character?
  5. Whose life are you involved in to helping to develop loving character?

Prayer Ideas and Additional Reading

  • Pray through some challenges we face in our character that we have been battling since childhood. The Bible teaches that these internal struggles can “only come out by prayer”- Mark 9:29.
  • Ecclesiastes 7:8, James 1:2-4 (MSG) ,
  • Book of James, Book of Romans

item.title: Breaking Free: Making the Right Choices
item.dc:creator: bacc
item.content:encoded:
This article is a part of a series of recaps from our recent Marriage Refreshment Weekend, which we’re calling “Faithfully: Class Notes.” We will continue to release these over the following week in order to give everyone a chance to revisit what they learned, and to give those who could not attend an opportunity to see what they missed.

Purpose

We all make choices every day in the kind of marriage and family we will build. Galatians 6:7 says that we will only reap what we sow. Our goal is to help us see the difference between a humanistic marriage and a spiritual marriage and to learn how to get the right motivation to make the right choices.

Scriptures

Galatians 6:7, Genesis 13:10-13, Genesis 19:1-2, Genesis 19:4-8, Genesis 19:15-16, Hebrews 12:15, Psalm 143:4, Psalm 32:3-4, Genesis 19:17-20, Genesis 19:21-26, Proverbs 16:2, Luke 17:33, Luke 5:4-6, Proverbs 20:5, Hebrews 10:38-39.

Idea 1: The Choice (humanistic or spiritual)

  • Genesis 13:10-13, Genesis 19:1-2, Genesis 19:4-8, Genesis 19:15-16, Hebrews 12:15, Psalm 143:4, Psalm 32:4
  • We all make a choice…will we be silent partners or a spiritual influence in our marriages and families
  • Bitterness, unbelief and guilt make us silent partners…
 

Idea 2: The Cost

  • Genesis 19:17-20, Genesis 19:21-26, Proverbs 16:2, Luke 17:33
  • We don’t consider the cost of our choices…the cost of this couples choice lead to…losing the dream God had for them, losing the marriage and losing the family
  • Motives matter to God because our motives leads to our choices
 

Idea 3: Breaking Free

  • Luke 5:4-6, Proverbs 20:5, Hebrews 10:38-39
  • 3 decisions to Break free and dream big…
  • Try again: putting our faith back in God
  • Let down: putting our heart back in our marriages
  • Look forward and dream big

Questions

  • What kind of home are we building- humanistic or spiritual?
  • What choices have we made that has affected our faith and marriage?
  • Am I easy to influence or am I resistant?
  • Am I a silent partner in our marriage? Why?
  • How have we settled for a small dream in our marriage?
  • What area in our marriage have we given up on that we should start trying again?
  • What area in my life do I have a hard time being vulnerable about?
  • What does “moving forward” look like in our marriage?

item.title: Choosing Transparency
item.dc:creator: bacc
item.content:encoded:
This article is a part of a series of recaps from our recent Marriage Refreshment Weekend, which we’re calling “Faithfully: Class Notes.” We will continue to release these over the following week in order to give everyone a chance to revisit what they learned, and to give those who could not attend an opportunity to see what they missed.

Purpose

Definition:
  1. Free from pretense or deceit
  2. Easily seen through
  3. Characterized by accessibility of information
Simply put, transparency is being known and being vulnerable, which is something we should consider if we want to have great relationships.
  • Q. How transparent are you as a person?
  • Q. Are you someone that others can read easily or do you freeze people out?
  • Q. Are you genuine with your thoughts and concerns or are you biting your tongue and hiding the hurtful thoughts inside.

Keys to Transparency

1. Known by God - this is a decision you have to make. It can’t be a rule, but a desire to want to be in relationship with Him 2. Known by your spouse - what are some keys to having spiritual conversations with your spouse so they are not an event but organic in your marriage? 3. Known by friends - how do you build a peer group?
  • Consider your needs
  • Not being insular
  • Who thinks different (a person you often feel misunderstood by)
  • Who tells you the truth
4. Having a home that is known
  • Having people in your home
  • Asking people what think or see
  • Giving your family permission to reach out and can talk about anything – Stop controlling the information
  • Changing your view of home – It’s not a hideout; it’s thanksgiving dinner
5. Known in the community
  • People love & fear transparency – Love it for others, fearful for yourselves
  • It sticks with people when you are not pretentious

Lesson

Choose to be Yourself
  • Genesis 12:1-5 - Lordship to Friendship
  • James 2:21-23 - Learning to listen & talk with God: the source of confidence to be yourself
Choose to Trust
  • Genesis 16: 1-2, 5 - Stop choosing blame
  • Genesis 18: 10-15 - Stop choosing unbelief & deceit
  • Hebrews 11: 11 (JB Philips) - Start choosing trust
Choose to Believe
  • Psalms 51: 6 - Overcoming the fear of pain
  • Psalm 139: 1, 23 - Being known
Chose to Attach
  • 1 Peter 3:1-6 (MSG) - Being responsive & open to seeing yourself differently
item.excerpt:encoded: Simply put, transparency is being known and being vulnerable, which is something we should consider if we want to have great relationships.

item.title: 2013 Events Are Right Around the Corner
item.dc:creator: bacc
item.content:encoded:
2012 has been a year unlike any other. We've seen a tremendous amount of growth in personal lives, the community, and as an organization, and we're confident 2013 will prove to up the ante even further. Every year at the BACC we host numerous events catered towards every major demographic in the Bay Area - Middle Schoolers and teens, college students, single and young married professionals, marrieds (with and without kids), and more. We also make a strong effort to have an increased presence in our local communities, with programs such as E-Soccer and E-Karate, which are recurring. These events would not be possible if not for the passion and efforts of our members, who have supported us tirelessly throughout the years. 2013 will continue to see such events take place, in addition to all the stories that we look forward to hearing about and sharing with our readers. The following events are set in stone, so feel free to mark your calendars for these today. Keep checking our site for updates on future events, and a 2013 calendar! Middle School & Teen Camps

  • Location: Koinonia Conference Grounds
Expo 2013
  • Dates: August 23-25
  • Location: Santa Clara Convention Center

item.title: Gratitude: The Holiday Game Changer
item.dc:creator: mikequery
item.content:encoded:
It has been said that gratitude should be expressed by a feeling in the heart, an expression in words and a giving in return. Every holiday season, "gratitude" becomes a popular topic. Yet its transformative power often eludes us.   The annual holiday specials on TV try to help us count our blessings and be thankful. However with the nonstop barrage of ads on TV and the internet fighting for our attention and our credit cards, contentment and gratitude are often far from our minds.  In fact, the opposite often occurs - each year many find themselves less and less happy with their possessions or their relationships, and the result can be a frustrating and futile battle for to grasp the true heart of Christmas. The Bible not only teaches us to be grateful it demands it.  This holiday season is a great opportunity to obey this often overlooked admonition and grow in our ability to be grateful.
Always be joyful. Pray continually, and give thanks whatever happens. That is what God wants for you in Christ Jesus. 1 Thessalonians 5:16-18 (NCV)
Gratitude will change your life regardless of your faith or affiliation.  In fact the following article addresses the power of gratitude, which the bibe has been teaching for thousands of years. In her article "The Transformative Power of Gratitude," Marilyn Price-Mitchell, Ph.D describes research (both hers and others' in the field) that speaks to the importance and strong effect that gratitude has on a micro and macro level:
The University of California Berkeley recently announced a $3.1 million research study on the power of gratitude. Through their Greater Good Science Center, they study the psychology, sociology, and neuroscience of well-being and how we foster a more thriving, resilient, and compassionate society. This research follows on the heels of many other studies showing that counting our blessings improves psychological, emotional, and physical well-being. In order to feel grateful, we must be present in the moment. And in order to teach our children the power of gratitude, they must feel our presence and appreciation each and every day. In my research with teens that had developed the capacity to care for others, they talked at length about gratitude. Their feelings emerged through authentic relationships with parents, mentors, and people who struggled to overcome poverty and injustices.
Teens who displayed gratitude in her research were shown to have a greater consciousness of what was going on around them and how people were feeling. One teen was quoted as saying “Having the opportunity to interact with people from different backgrounds and social histories has allowed me to see just how fortunate I am. I never take what my life has given me for granted.” Gratitude is something that leads not only to avoiding the stress of trying to keep up with others during the holiday season, but transforms us into people who are capable of caring and changing lives. So this Christmas, instead of counting down the days till the next Best Buy sale, try counting your blessings instead. The results will be better than you think. If you want to a great book to study to further help you grow in this area study the book of Colossians
item.excerpt:encoded: The Transformative impact of Gratitude can change your Holiday experience

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Gratitude: More Powerful Than You Probably Realize
There's a reason God makes a big deal about being thankful no matter what happens.

It has been said that gratitude should be expressed by a feeling in the heart, an expression in words and a giving in return.
Every holiday season, "gratitude" becomes a popular topic. Yet its transformative power often eludes us. The annual holiday specials on TV try to help us count our blessings and be thankful. However with the nonstop barrage of ads on TV and the internet fighting for our attention and our credit cards, contentment and gratitude are often far from our minds. In fact, the opposite often occurs - each year many find themselves less and less happy with their possessions or their relationships, and the result can be a frustrating and futile battle for to grasp the true heart of Christmas.

item.title: 5 Exciting Date Spots in the Bay Area
item.dc:creator: mikequery
item.content:encoded:
It's impossible to encapsulate the uniqueness and impressiveness of the Bay Area in one article. There's a reason that San Francisco is continually named America's #1 ranked city year after year. People come here for a reason, and it's rare the city disappoints. Our upcoming professionals retreat, entitled "Open Your Eyes," will see hundreds of Bay Area professionals come together to find purpose and build new relationships. For out of towners, or even those who've been here a long time and forget how special a place they live in, we thought it'd be appropriate and helpful to provide you with a list of our favorite date spots in the Bay Area. This is not so much a restaurant or location review guide...you can visit Yelp for that. Rather, this is a list of spots that will give you and your date plenty to do, and will provide an environment conducive for great conversation with minimal pressure.

1. Pier 39/Fisherman's Wharf

Pier 39, located on the edge of the Fisherman's Wharf district, is one of the most popular tourist attractions in San Francsico. It's also a must try date experience, as it offers plenty of fun activities, good food, and interesting conversation starters. Whether it's watching a unique street performance, observing the peculiar sea lions, or lose your breath at the sight of Alcatraz and the Golden Gate bridge, there is enough to do at Pier 39 to keep you and your date talking and laughing for an entire afternoon or evening.

2. Santa Cruz

Santa Cruz is, similar to Half Moon Bay, a go-to location for people hoping to take in the ocean and small, beach town life. It's a small enough city to be considered a date spot, as you can drive through the entire town in the same amount of time it takes to get through a few blocks of San Francisco. If you plan a date during the day, there are plenty of breathtaking views of the ocean you can observe by setting up shop at the legendary Natural Bridges state park, or by taking a walk down West Cliff Drive. If you arrive at night, the city is loaded with great restaurants and live music venues, all packed together in a small, two street downtown scene. There are plenty of things going on here to make for building great memories together.

3. Yoshi's Jazz Club

Every once in awhile, it's fun to dress nice and go to someplace that makes you feel classy. Yoshi's Jazz Club lets you do this at a price that doesn't leave you feeling like you won't be able to cover rent. With two locations in the Bay (one in Oakland, and a newer one in San Francisco), Yoshi's is a wonderful environment with exceptional sushi dishes and hosts the top names in jazz today. You don't really have to know who exactly those are, but just know that as the music plays while you're at your private table, you'll be treating your date to an experience he/she won't forget.

4. Jack London Square

Jack London Square, located in the heart of Oakland, is a beautiful downtown area that provides the visitor with plenty to do while taking in the less talked about view of the San Francisco Bay. If you're planning a date here, take a look at the event calendar to see what special activities you can organize the afternoon or evening around.

5. California Academy of Sciences

There's something about observing nature that allows people to let their guard down and be themselves. There is so much spectacular stuff to take in at the California Academy of Sciences that you will unlikely see everything in one date. Take a trip under the sea in the aquarium, hang out with some penguins, walk through the rain forest, have your mind blown in the planetarium, and have fun learning about our planet in ways you didn't think possible. It should provide you and your date with more topics to talk about than you know what to do with!
item.excerpt:encoded: Great spots that will give you and your date plenty to do, and will provide an environment conducive for great conversation with minimal pressure.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: 5 Exciting Date Spots in the Bay Area

item.title: VIDEO: XCED Children's Book Touches Lives, to be Published in September
item.dc:creator: mikequery
item.content:encoded: XCED is a group of young people who want to exceed society’s low expectation of teenagers – they believe that students are capable of having a real influence on their communities. Standing for “Extra-Curricular Educational Development,” XCED is striving to change the culture in our schools and communities regarding inclusion. Some of our teens have siblings who are adopted or have special needs, and they know what it feelslike to be excluded. They have two goals. The first is to help these kids, and many others, to feel included. The second is to help them exceed far beyond their limitations and soar above society’s expectations. Watch this video that does a great job explaining what XCED is up to. XCED - Expo 2012 from BACC Video on Vimeo.

item.title: VIDEO: SpeakOut Making Waves on Campus at SJSU
item.dc:creator: mikequery
item.content:encoded: This year at the BACC's annual Expo, we were treated to back to back videos that highlighted the community impact made by campus and teens in the BACC. Both XCED and SpeakOut are community service initiatives started by students that are anxious to do something significant in their communities, and both of these videos managed to effectively capture their passion. SpeakOut is a student run club at San Jose State University, and has already managed to garner an impressive amount of support on campus. The club hopes to spread the message of inclusion, which is a methodology adopted and made famous by E-Soccer, which is a program almost all their members participate in as coaches. So far, they've managed to bolster support for local E-Soccer programs, and it's spreading quickly across campus as their cause receives funding for the next school year. Check out the video below to learn more about how SpeakOut is impacting the community. SpeakOut - Expo 2012 from BACC Video on Vimeo.

item.title: E-Soccer Fall Season Under Way
item.dc:creator: mikequery
item.content:encoded: September marks the return to school for both high school and college students, which is typically associated with a sense of either dread, excitement, or a combination of both. Fortunately for students looking for ways to be active in their community (or to just work the college apps), the fall E-Soccer season is officially under way, which should provide an outlet and renewed sense of purpose for those quickly feeling like they're sinking back into a grind. Last season, E-Soccer saw a number of special events occur that exemplify how far the program has grown since its inception in 2000. Collegiate soccer teams from San Francisco State University, Cal Berkeley and Sonoma State hosted a tournament to support E-Soccer; SFSU has also become a semi-regular contributor to the program. In addition, students at San Jose State University launched a new club called SpeakOut, which is growing rapidly as students enter the Fall semester. SpeakOut has already managed to acquire funding that will be used to support E-Soccer, particularly in the Santa Clara location as it is closer in proximity to participating universities. There are now E-Soccer sessions taking place in 10 different locations around the Bay Area, as well as out of state and out of country. E-Soccer Las Vegas, the newest host and first autonomous U.S. program to launch and sustain itself out of California, is growing strong and regrouping as they prepare for their next season. Lots of things to look forward to for E-Soccer as we move into the Autumn. Local high schools are launching clubs to recruit members who are itching to get their hands on valuable community service hours. More to come on that as we move towards the last leg of 2012. Sign up online at E-Soccer's official website if you're interested in becoming a coach, or if you're interested in having your child attend one of the active locations.
item.excerpt:encoded: The fall E-Soccer season is officially under way after strong spring and summer seasons.

item.title: BACC Makes “Fearless” Impact in East Palo Alto Schools
item.dc:creator: aeburnett
item.content:encoded: In just a few short weeks, the impact and inspiration of our 2012 BACC Expo “Fearless” is already reaching the lives of high school students in East Palo Alto. After the Expo, the BACC donated backpacks, water bottles, and pens with the “Fearless” logo on them to East Palo Alto Academy High School. The “Fearless” bags immediately began to make a difference as Remi Sobomehin, the school's varsity basketball coach and Restorative Justice Coordinator, used the donations to set up a “Fearless” Student of the Week program. Every Thursday, the program honors students who stand up for what is right - even when it’s not popular. These students receive a “fearless” backpack, pen and water bottle and have their picture posted in the showcase in the front hallway of the school. Additionally, Sobomeheim runs a fitness elective at the school and on the first day gave each of the students a water bottle and backpack after announcing the theme for the class would be “Fearless.” The first health concept for the class was the importance of drinking water, and every kid vowed to try to drink 6 bottles worth of water every day. “They were so excited and beasted through the first day of workouts,” said Sobomehin, “So encouraging to see… Much love and appreciation to BACC for the donation.” [caption id="attachment_752" align="aligncenter" width="300"] You'd be excited to get a free bag too[/caption] At the BACC, we are excited to contribute to our community and to help inspire these young men and women to become fearless and reach their potential in every area of their lives. We look forward to many more stories of “fearless” impact in the weeks to come!

item.title: 2012 XCED Toy Drive Collects Over 1,600 Toys
item.dc:creator: mikequery
item.content:encoded:
Yesterday the BACC hosted its annual Holiday Celebration service at the Santa Clara Convention Center, which saw thousands in attendance from all over the Bay. For the fifth year in a row, XCED organized and held a charity toy drive. This annual toy drive has  become one of the biggest toy drives in Northern California. This year XCED had one of its most successful events to-date with over 1,600 toys donated (400 more than last year's toy drive). The toy drive has evolved into a Bay Area community service landmark event. In the five years since its inception, over 8,600 toys have been donated to various agencies from both sides of the Bay. Of the 10,000 kids in Bay Area foster homes, over 5,000 of them have received support from XCED via 15 different agencies. Over 50 teens participated in the drive, manning the collection tables at the Holiday Celebration Service, or by setting up bins and drives at their schools and local business. One West Bay Christian School student was even able to make it their school's official community service project, allowing for more students to get involved who had not yet heard of XCED. "I was crying at my desk on Friday because I realized I had so many teenagers who I didn’t have any gifts for," Lisvet Carillo-Herrera, a representitive from Santa Clara Socials (which serves over 500 foster children) shared. "I came with hope of finding gifts for them and am so grateful to have received thousands of dollars worth of gift cards for these teenagers." It's been a big and ambitious year for the organization, which is comprised primarily of high school volunteers in the Bay Area. Earlier in the year they published a children's book entitled "Better Together," which addresses the complex emotions surrounding growing up with a sibling with special needs. The story was inspired by XCED member's own experiences. Sharing their experiences has raised awareness as well has helped many in families with special needs. Here are some highlights from this year's toy drive:
  •  Over 1,600 toys donated
  • Most gift cards ever received
  • Most cash in donations ever received
  • Most agencies ever donated to on one day - Bananas Incorporated, United Advocates of Children & Families of Alameda, A Better Way, Sleep Train, UCSF, California Pacific Medical Center, Unity Care, Santa Clara Social Services
  • Agencies represented from all five major counties in the Bay Area - Contra Costa, Santa Clara, San Mateo, San Francisco and Alameda

item.title: 5 Ideas for Community Service Activities from BACC Members
item.dc:creator: mikequery
item.content:encoded:
In the last few weeks, BACC members from across both sides of the Bay have organized various community service efforts to provide options and opportunities for the less fortunate during the holiday season. The efforts ranged from being fairly involved outreach activities, to simple enough events that can be done in the home with friends or family. Since you may be looking for some last minute opportunities to get involved in your local community, we thought we'd share some of their stories to give you some inspiration to exercise your good will.

1. Holiday dinner basket (effort level: low)

ShelterNetwork, a terrific volunteering hub that recently partnered with InnVision, is a Bay Area nonprofit that focuses on fighting hunger and homelessness. They offer numerous ways to get involved in helping the less fortunate over the holidays, including activities like setting up holiday parties, or just giving a flat donation. One great way to contribute is to take advantage of their Holiday Dinner Basket program. BACC members have already held several events which consist of meeting together at a home, taking a trip to the grocery store and purchasing an assortment of goods together in order to assemble a meal which will be transported to families who would otherwise have nothing to eat during Thanksgiving or Christmas dinners. Shelter Network even provides a list of items to acquire for the basket, making the shopping experience fairly effortless. After purchasing the goods, the BACC members assembled the baskets together and then delivered them to local shelters, the locations of which are provided by Shelter Network. Check out Shelter Network and InnVision's holiday giving page for more information on how to get started. Dinner baskets cost roughly $40 after purchasing all the items.

2. Coat and food drives (effort level: medium)

The Peninsula Jewish Community Center (PJCC) also offer several ways to get involved over the next couple of weeks. One program of theirs that has been popular among BACC members has been their coat drive. This activity involves gathering as many coats as possible from family, friends, neighbors and even strangers to donate to the homeless. The effort here is mostly in arranging for the collection of the coats, so if you plan on heading up one of these activities, make sure to arrange for a place to store the coats for the duration of your drive. The PJCC also runs a food drive, which operates in a similar fashion. Visit PJCC's giving page to learn more about how to get involved.

3. Dinner party for local youth (effort level: high)

In East Palo Alto, some BACC members organized a Holiday Dinner for members of the EPA Academy's basketball teams, both boys and girls. Remi Sobomehin, head coach and community crusader, arranged to use the school's library to host the event. Of all the ideas presented in this article, this one involves probably the most work, just because there's a fair amount of things to organize, including:
  • Coordinating with school or youth organization administration
  • Planning food and decoration arrangements
  • Ensuring buy in and support from parents
But the work is definitely worth it. Seeing the look on kids' faces when they receive something they were not expecting is irreplaceable. Try contacting local schools or foster homes in your area to get an idea for how you can get started in your community.

4. Adopt-a-family (effort level: low)

Another great way to put a smile on some faces this year is to adopt a family. The idea is similar to the Dinner Baskets idea mentioned earlier, but this one allows you to make a personal connection with the people that your giving is supporting. The basic premise is, you work with an organization like Shelter Network to learn about different families in need and, after hearing more about who they are and what they need, contribute something that will help make their holiday season a little brighter. In some cases you're able to meet the families, giving your donations in person and establishing a relationship. In others they'd prefer to remain anonymous. Either way, it's great being able to see the fruits of your giving, and is sure to encourage future social contributions from everyone involved. Check out Compass Family Services or Glide for more information on how to get involved in Adopt-a-Family

5. Volunteer Match (effort level: variable)

For those that would like to give but are still unsure as to how or where to go about doing so, look no further than VolunteerMatch.org. Volunteer Match is a rich listing site with countless opportunities available across all ends of the volunteering spectrum. Just about anyone can search for a way to get involved in their community, as the service allows you to search for serving opportunities by location and by need. The activities involved are incredibly diverse; BACC members have used it this season to participate in everything from homeless shelter volunteering to web design for low budget nonprofits. So if you're still stuck even after reading these suggestions, take some time combing through Volunteer Match and you'll very likely end up finding a way to give back that you didn't know existed.

item.title: Good Marketing: How the Power of Marketing Can Change the World
item.dc:creator: mikequery
item.content:encoded: Many professionals in the Bay Area wonder how to use their talents to make a difference. Even those who aspire to excel in business have similar aspirations of promoting social causes and making lasting impact. As innovators in our community, it’s important to ask ourselves what good are we going to do with all of our talents? Several weeks ago on November, I had the privilege to introduce a good friend, John Coyne, as a guest speaker at Santa Clara University’s Graduate Business School. The event, which was hosted by a student group called Net Impact, was called, “Good Marketing: How the power of marketing can change the world.” It was a spectacular event considering that about 40+ students showed up on a Friday evening to listen to a panel discussion (a night when most would choose to party and otherwise socialize!). As one of two guest speakers, John wowed the crowd with fascinating stories of his experience working at Goodby Silverstein & Partners, a world-renown advertising company based out of San Francisco. He spoke about how doing good and doing business can go hand in hand; that, contrary to popular opinion, you can be a marketer without have to do bad all day. He also shared a video relating to how his efforts to promote Hacking Autism and a partnership with Hewlett Packard has made an incredible impact not only at his company but also at HP. The audience also had a chance to ask questions relating to what a lot of us may be thinking. How can we make an impact using our talents as professionals in the Bay Area? John’s answer was very compelling. He said that we should figure out what causes we are passionate about (whether it be helping out foster children, children with special needs, developing nations, etc.) and start doing something. It can be anything as long as we are determined to put in effort to see our visions come true. I could tell that people were enthusiastic for the topic because they had so many good follow up questions and really wanted to keep the conversation going. At the conclusion of the event, we all hung around for a bit of meet and greet. It wasn’t difficult to strike up conversations about ideas for doing good in business because we already had heard from someone taking action. Everyone was feeling good about possibilities of doing good and many new relationships were built. What good do you want to do in the future and what relationships will you build to help make your ideas into reality?

item.title: National Day of Service: Participate by Volunteering for E-Soccer
item.dc:creator: bacc
item.content:encoded:
On January 19th, President Obama is asking all citizens to participate in a tradition his family started in 2009, and spend the day doing service work in communities across the country. This newly recognized event is being called a National Day of Service, and it takes place just days before Martin Luther King Jr. Day, which served as the inspiration for the holiday. Chelsea Clinton, daughter of former President Bill Clinton and current Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, has recently taken it upon herself to advocate for the cause by encouraging citizens to rally together to volunteer and take action:
"When I was growing up, both my parents and grandparents instilled a commitment to service in me," Clinton said in a statement provided to The Associated Press by the Presidential Inaugural Committee. "They taught me that helping our neighbors and serving our community were essential parts of being a good citizen and a good person." Source: MSNBC
Service strengthens communities as people become invested to helping others in their neighborhoods. When individuals and families get together to benefit a cause or help in service programs it creates an atmosphere of togetherness, solidarity in the community. The Bay Area Christian Church believes in helping and serving our communities all across the Bay Area. We have been serving the community over thirteen years year round through our “E,” Exceptional Children’s Programs, such as E-Soccer. This Saturday we invite you to join us at our E-Soccer program. E-Soccer is an all-volunteer, inclusive soccer program where typical and special needs children aged 5 and up participate alongside each other in an inclusive environment. We are dedicated to empowering children of all abilities to reach their full athletic and social potential. For those who will participate this weekend our hope is that this Saturday only marks the beginning of a lifelong commitment to doing good in our communities. If you're interested in participating in National Service Day by volunteering at E-Soccer, you can sign up online on the National Day of Service website. If you're looking for more ways to volunteer, you can also use the site to check out other community service events taking place in your area.

item.title: Open Your Eyes: What it is and Why We Need It
item.dc:creator: mvives
item.content:encoded:
The San Francisco Bay Area is ranked as the number one place to live in the United States by Bloomberg’s BusinessWeek.  With its unique geographical landscapes, innovative atmosphere and entrepreneurial culture, San Francisco attracts a large population of brilliant and forward-thinking single professionals and young marrieds from around the world.

The Bay Area is home to some of the most highly regarded businesses in the world. Drew Houston, Co-Founder and CEO of Dropbox says, “We’re proud to call San Francisco our home; there’s no better place in the world for creative thinkers and builders.”

According to the United States Census Bureau, the San Francisco Bay Area has “the highest percentages of singles of any large city in the United States with 80% of households in San Francisco are either singles or marrieds with no children”. The founders and the workforce behind these successful companies are predominantly singles or young marrieds; for our purposes we can define them as professionals.

In recent years there has been a rise in online dating and its dependence on entering the dating scene in the Bay Area. Sam Yagan of New-York based OK Cupid says, “We have the most fans in San Francisco and probably our biggest penetration of any market”.

The challenge that professionals face is the pressure to balance a career and a personal life. The struggle is to not be defined by what you do, but putting a greater emphasis on developing the kind of person you want to become.

It is important to understand that what you value will shape the person you become. This highly influences the relationships that you build and affects the people you attract. Unless you know who you are, what you believe, and what you value-- you don’t know what you are looking for.

It’s our great privilege to announce the 2013 Professionals Retreat, “Open Your Eyes”! The purpose of this retreat is to use and apply biblical principles to discover and develop into the person you are to become. There will be inspiring workshops and fun activities for  single professionals, dating and young married couples and single parents. It truly be a memorable time!

I pray that the eyes of your heart may be enlightened in order that you may know the hope to which he has called you, the riches of his glorious inheritance in his holy people.                                                                                                - Ephesians 1:18

item.title: 8 Reasons Why You Should Go on Numerous Dates
item.dc:creator: joji
item.content:encoded: Invest what you have, because after a while you will get a return. 2 Invest what you have in several different businesses, because you don’t know what disasters might happen. If clouds are full of rain, they will shower on the earth. A tree can fall to the north or south, but it will stay where it falls. 4 Those who wait for perfect weather will never plant seeds; those who look at every cloud will never harvest crops. You don’t know where the wind will blow, and you don’t know how a baby grows inside the mother. In the same way, you don’t know what God is doing, or how he created everything. Ecclesiastes 11:1-5 (NCV) God is all about investing. He is all about taking initiative. Taking chances. Often we apply this philosophy to financial investments and job selection but it applies to relationships as well. Going on lots of dates has many benefits, but it's important that you go into them with the right perspective. So here are 8 phenomenal reasons why you should be a dating machine: 1. It takes the pressure off finding “the one” You know you’ve got many dates lined up so you can just relax and have good time getting to know someone new or enjoy going out with a familiar friend 2. More opportunities to connect with people You get to know more people this way and the more connections, the better. 3. Opportunity to Refine your Character As you get to know people, you will get to know yourself better. People have the ability to reveal parts of our character we wouldn’t be able to see without them. For example, they reveal how shallow we can be. And you know what I mean… 4. Opportunity to develop conviction of about who you need vs. who/what you want It’s an opportunity to compare and contrast qualities and how they mesh with you. You get to figure out what you are really looking for in a relationship. Think of it as going from regular television to HD 3D in IMAX. 5. You evaluate what nuances you can and cannot handle in a relationship You find out whether the woman/man of your dreams is worth it as they smack while eating their food; laugh obnoxiously or talk too much. 6. The Connection Effect News travels, impressions travel. Maybe you won't end up dating the person but they have a friend that they think you may be perfect for – and he/she is “the one”. 7. You get better at dating You would think we all know how to date. But it’s not true. There’s a process and a steep learning curve as well. Things like, confidence, being able to communicate effectively, and being able to read people take practice. So the more dates you go on, the better. And hopefully, that first or second date you bombed on, will give you another chance later on and vice versa 8. It Speeds up the Process of Meeting the Right Person The more dates you go on, the higher your chances are of finding, “the one”. So, what are you waiting for? On your mark, get set, date! (Lots of people)
